Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, Town of Davie, Florida" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1964, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
(a)  Definition. In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Charter. The word charter shall mean the charter of the Town of Davie. 
    Code. The term code shall mean the Code of Ordinances, Town of Davie, Florida. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done as provided in this Code or in any order issued pursuant to this Code or any ordinance, when expressed in days, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, except that if the last day be Sunday it shall be excluded; and when any such time is expressed in hours the whole of Sunday, from midnight to midnight, shall be excluded. 
    Conflicts. If the provisions of different chapters of this Code conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter shall prevail as to all matters and questions growing out of the subject matter of such chapter. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Broward. 
    Delegation. When a provision of this Code requires an act to be done which may by law as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent. 
    Gender; singular and plural. Every word in any ordinance importing the masculine gender shall extend to and be applied to females as well as males; and every word importing the singular number only shall extend and be applied to several persons or things as well as to one person or thing; and every word importing the plural number only shall extend and be applied to one person or thing as well as to several persons or things. 
    Joint authority. All words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more city officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons unless it shall be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner", applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property includes every species of property except real property. 
    Reasonable time. In all cases where any provision of this Code shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such duty, or compliance with such notice. 
    References. All reference to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
    Tense. The use of any verb in the present tense shall include the future when applicable. 
    Town. The words "the town" or "this town" shall be construed as if the words "of Davie" followed the word town, and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
    Town boards, commissions, department officials, officers or employees. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, departments, etc., by title only, they shall be deemed to refer to the officials, boards, commissions and departments of the Town of Davie. 
    Town council. Whenever the words "council" or "town council" are used, they shall be construed to mean the Town Council of the Town of Davie. 
    Town treasurer. The town treasurer shall be the town clerk. 
    State. The words, "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
    Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven days; but publication in a newspaper of any notice or other matter indicated to be for a stated number of weeks shall be construed to mean one insertion in each week, unless specifically stated to be for each day of the week or for more than one day in each week; and all publications heretofore made in accordance with the terms of this subsection are hereby validated. 
(b)  General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(c)  When these rules of construction shall not apply. The rules of construction set forth in this section shall not be applied to any part of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when the subject matter or context of such provision may be repugnant thereto. 
(Code 1964, § 1-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions for the alcoholic beverage chapter, § 3-1; definitions for the article on livestock, § 4-41; definitions for article on dogs, § 4-61; definitions for dangerous buildings article, § 5-66; definitions for article on excavation, § 5-141; definitions for chapter on garbage and refuse, 9-1; definitions for article on collection and removal of garbage and refuse, § 9-21; definitions for chapter on junk, abandoned, wrecked property, § 11-16; definitions chapter on landscaping, § 12-1; definitions for the business taxes, § 13-16; definitions of adult entertainment and massage parlors, etc., § 13-66. 
State Law reference- Definitions of terms used, F.S. § 1.01. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of this section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. No provision of this Code shall be held invalid by reason of deficiency in any such catchline or in any heading or title to any chapter, article or division. 
(Code 1964, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal or amendment of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect, nor the obligation of any contract entered into under the prior ordinance. 
(b)  The repeal or amendment of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal or amendment took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal or amendment for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed or amended. 
(Code 1964, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- "No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, nor any law impairing the obligation of contracts, shall ever be passed," Florida Constitution, art. I, § 10. 
Sec. 1-5. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by the town, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the town, or any evidence of the town indebtedness, or any contract agreement, lease, deed, or other instrument or obligation assumed by the town; 
(2)  Any administrative ordinances; 
(3)  Any right or franchise, permit or other right granted by any ordinance; 
(4)  Any ordinance establishing positions, classifying positions and setting salaries of town officers and employees; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, alley or other public way in the town; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades in the town; 
(7)  Any personnel regulations; 
(8)  Any zoning or land use ordinance or any rezoning ordinance; 
(9)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory from the town; 
(10)  Any ordinance establishing a pension or retirement plan; 
(11)  Any appropriation ordinance or any ordinance levying or imposing taxes or fees; 
(12)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(13)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the town; 
(14)  Any ordinance establishing the official plat of the town, the zoning map or any amendments thereof; 
(15)  Any ordinance prescribing traffic and parking regulations for specific streets and locations; 
(16)  Any temporary or special ordinance; 
(17)  Any ordinance regulating utilities or setting rates for utilities and charges as amended; 
(18)  Any provisions of Chapter 61-2056, Laws of Florida, as amended by special law or otherwise, which have been converted to ordinances by F.S. Section 166.021 and have not been superseded or repealed; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are re-adopted as a new Code by the town council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Davie, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...". The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code, is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Davie, Florida, is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows: ...". The section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1964, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the town to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1964, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Altering, forging, etc., of public record for purposes of defrauding F.S. §§ 831.01, 839.13. 
Sec. 1-8. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-9. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code shall be punished as provided for in this section. 
(b)  A person convicted of a violation of this Code or a person who has entered a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere to a violation of that Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the judge of the appropriate court of competent jurisdiction. The trial court, in its discretion, may also place a defendant on probation, alone or in conjunction with the above penalties. With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(c)  In addition to the penalties hereinabove provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be, by the town, abated as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(d)  Probation. "Probation" means a form of town supervision requiring specified contacts with the Town of Davie Work Program Administrator, and other terms and conditions as hereinafter provided. 
(1)  Terms and conditions of probation. The court shall determine the terms and conditions of probation and may include among them the following, that the probationer shall: 
a.  Report to the town's work program administrator, as directed, to perform community service work. In lieu of such participation, the court may order that a defendant pay an additional fine of ten dollars ($10.00) for each hour of community service work otherwise required. 
b.  Work faithfully at suitable employment insofar as may be possible. 
c.  Make reparation or restitution to the aggrieved party for the damage or loss caused by his offense in an amount to be determined by the court. The court shall make such reparation or restitution a condition of probation, unless it determines that clear and compelling reasons exist to the contrary. If the court does not order restitution, or orders restitution of only a portion of the damages, it shall state on the record in detail the reasons therefor. 
(2)  Condition of probation-restitution. If a defendant is placed on probation, any restitution ordered shall be a condition of such probation. The court may revoke probation if the defendant fails to comply with such order. In determining whether to revoke probation, the court shall consider the defendant's employment status, earning ability, and financial resources; the willfulness of the defendant's failure to pay; and any other special circumstances that may have a bearing on the defendant's ability to pay. 
(3)  Violation of probation; revocation; modification; continuance. 
a.  Whenever within the period of probation there are reasonable grounds to believe that a probationer has violated his probation in a material respect, the town's work program administrator may request a town law enforcement officer to arrest such probationer without warrant wherever found and forthwith return him to the court granting such probation. Any committing magistrate may issue a warrant, upon the facts being made known to him by affidavit of one having knowledge of such facts, for the arrest of the probationer, returnable forthwith before the court granting such probation. Any parole or probation supervisor, any officer authorized to serve criminal process, or any peace officer of this state is authorized to serve and execute such warrant. The court, upon the probationer being brought before it, shall advise him of such charge of violation and, if such charge is admitted to be true, may forthwith revoke, modify or continue the probation. If probation is revoked, the court shall adjudge the probationer guilty of the offense charged and proven or admitted, unless he has previously been adjudged guilty, and impose any sentence which it might have originally imposed before placing the probationer on probation. If such violation of probation is not admitted by the probationer, the court may commit him or release him with or without bail to await further hearing, or it may dismiss the charge of probation. If such charge is not at that time admitted by the probationer and if it is not dismissed, the court, as soon as may be practicable, shall give the probationer an opportunity to be fully heard on his behalf in person or by counsel. After such hearing, the court may revoke, modify or continue the probation. If such probation is revoked, the court shall adjudge the probationer or offender guilty of the offense charged and proven or admitted, unless he has previously been adjudged guilty, and impose any sentence which it might have originally imposed before placing the probationer on probation. 
b.  No part of the time that the defendant is on probation shall be considered as any part of the time that he shall be sentenced to serve. 
c.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, a probationer who is arrested for violating his probation in a material respect may be taken before the court in the county in which he was arrested. That court shall advise him of such charge of a violation and, if such charge is admitted, shall cause him to be brought before the court which granted the probation. If such probation is not admitted by the probationer, the court may commit him or release him with or without bail to await further hearing. The court, as soon as is practicable, shall give the probationer an opportunity to be fully heard on his behalf in person or by counsel. After such hearing, the court shall make findings of fact and forward the findings to the court which granted the probation and to the probationer or his attorney. The findings of fact by the hearing court are binding on the court which granted the probation. Upon the probationer being brought before it, the court which granted the probation may revoke, modify or continue the probation. 
(4)  Failure to pay restitution. In any hearing in which the failure of a probationer to pay restitution is established by the town, if the probationer asserts his inability to pay restitution, it is incumbent upon him to prove by clear and convincing evidence that he does not have the present resources available to pay restitution despite sufficient bona fide efforts legally to acquire the resources to do so. If the probationer cannot pay restitution despite sufficient bona fide efforts, the court shall consider alternate measures of punishment other than imprisonment. Only if alternate measures are not adequate to meet the town's interests in punishment and deference may the court imprison a probationer who has demonstrated sufficient bona fide efforts to pay restitution. 
(Code 1964, § 1-8; Ord. No. 92-40, § 1, 10-8-92) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Refunds of amounts paid for permits issued by town departments-Procedure generally. 
    No person shall be entitled to any refund of the amount paid for any permit issued by any department of the town unless such refund is applied for in writing within six (6) months from the date of issuance of such permit, or within the extended time thereof if the same has been extended under an applicable ordinance. 
(Code 1967, 1-10) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; garbage and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; floodplain management, § 12-541 et seq.; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 13; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 17; planning and development, Ch. 18; signs and advertising, Ch. 20; streets, sidewalks, and other public places, Ch. 21; subdivisions, Ch. 22; vegetation, Ch. 26; zoning, Ch. 27; rebate of license taxes, § 13-28. 
Sec. 2-2. - Same-Service charge. 
    The town department which issues a permit for which a refund is claimed pursuant to the preceding section shall, before making any such refund, retain and deduct therefrom a sum equal to ten (10) percent of the amount originally paid for the permit, which sum shall constitute a service charge and shall be paid into the town treasury. 
(Code 1967, § 1-11) 
Sec. 2-3. - Insurance on town vehicles. 
(a)  The council hereby sets minimum insurance coverages of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage and one hundred thousand dollars/two hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00/$200,000.00) bodily injury coverage. 
(b)  The aforementioned minimum insurance coverages shall be applicable to all town owned vehicles registered in the state. 
(Code 1964, § 2-10) 
Sec. 2-4. - Request for information concerning town liens. 
    Whenever the town receives a request for an accounting of the amounts of any outstanding town liens, a fee shall be charged for providing the information in response to each request. The amount of the fee shall be determined by resolution by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 91-35, § 1, 9-19-91) 
Secs. 2-5-2-20. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-39. - Expense reimbursements to mayor and town council members for out-of-pocket expenses. 
(a)  Each member of the town council of the Town of Davie shall receive the sum of four hundred and fifty dollars ($450.00) per month as reimbursement for out-of-pocket expenses. 
(b)  The mayor of the town shall receive the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month as reimbursement for out-of-pocket expenses. 
(Code 1964, § 2-7; Ord. No. 85-70, § 1, 8-21-85; Ord. No. 2015-014, § 2, 5-20-15) 
Sec. 2-40. - Vacancy in candidacy. 
(a)  In the event of the withdrawl, death or removal of a qualified candidate or candidates for an elected municipal office following the end of the qualifying period which results in one (1) candidate remaining on the ballot for that office, the remaining candidate shall be declared elected and no election for that office shall be required. 
(b)  In the event of the withdrawl, death or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate or candidates following the end of the qualifying period which results in no candidates remaining for that office, the council shall within the next three (3) ensuing regular council meetings, appoint a successor to such office by a vote of at least three (3) council members. The appointed official shall serve until the next regularly scheduled general election or an election held by the county, whichever should occur first. The appointee shall have such qualifications (including district resident requirements) as prescribed for in the Charter for such office. If the council should fail to appoint a successor to the vacant office within the next three (3) ensuing regular meetings after such a vacancy should occur, a special election shall then be proclaimed to elect a successor to serve the balance of the unexpired term. 
(c)  The name of any qualified candidate who has withdrawn, died or been removed from the ballot shall not be printed on the ballot. If the ballot cannot be changed, any votes for that candidate shall be null and void. 
(d)  A candidate who withdraws or is removed from the ballot after having qualified and paid the qualification fee shall not receive a refund of the qualifying fee. 
(Ord. No. 93-39, § 1, 1-15-93)

Sec. 2-42. - Interference with administration. 
    Neither the town council nor any of its members shall direct the appointment of any person to office or employment by the town administrator, or in any manner prevent the town administrator from using his own judgment in selecting those officers or employees which he is entitled to appoint or select under provisions of the Charter of the town or other applicable rules and regulations. In the event the council or any member thereof gives a direct order to any subordinate of the town administrator, either publicly or privately, which will require the expenditure of substantial time, the subordinate shall request authorization from the town administrator or designee to proceed to act on the order. Should the authorization from the town administrator or designee not be forthcoming, the subordinate shall take no further action with regard to the order of the council or councilmember. Nothing herein contained shall restrict the power of the council at regular or special meetings by formal motion, resolution or ordinance to establish policies and require compliance therewith by all personnel in the service of the town. 
(Ord. No. 98-34, § 1, 8-5-98) 
Sec. 2-43. - Council powers and duties. 
    The Council powers and duties as set forth in Section 7(C) of the Town Charter shall include, but not be limited to, Councilmembers serving on all boards upon appointment by the Town Council, including, but not limited to, pension or retirement boards; unless otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 99-39, §1, 11-3-99) 
Secs. 2-44-2-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REGISTRATION OF LOBBYISTS 

Sec. 2-56. - Intent and purpose. 
    The town council of the Town of Davie determines and declares that, to maintain the integrity of the government decision making process, the Town of Davie Councilmembers, staff and residents have a legitimate need to know certain information about the activities of "lobbyists", as defined in this article. The town council also finds that "lobbying", as defined in this article, is a legitimate form of free speech, which is frequently an important and necessary part of the legislative process. As such, this article seeks to impose the least burden which is reasonably necessary on lobbyists, in order to satisfy this public need for information. 
(Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 2012-17, § 1, 8-15-12; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Sec. 2-57. - Definitions. 
    Candidate means an individual who is conducting a campaign for an elected office in the Town of Davie, Florida. 
    Campaign means the election process for any elected municipal official whether opposed or not and whether a special or regular election, beginning with the date of officially filing for office with the town clerk and ending with the last day of voting which finally determines the outcome of the election. 
    Contractor means any person or entity currently under contract with the Town of Davie. 
    Covered individual means (i) any member of the Town of Davie Council; (ii) any member of a final decision-making body under the Town of Davie; (iii) any individual directly appointed to a town employment position by the town council; (iv) any individual serving on a contractual basis as the town attorney or town administrator, when such individual is acting in his or her official capacity; (v) any member of a selection, evaluation, or procurement committee that ranks or makes recommendations to the town council regarding a municipal procurement; (vi) any employee, any official, or any member of a committee of the town that has authority to make a final decision regarding a public procurement; and (vii) the head of any department, division, or office of the town who makes final recommendations to the town council regarding items that will be decided by the final decision-making authority. For purposes of the prohibition on lobbying [as defined herein], "covered individual" also includes members of other local governmental entities within Broward County, including authorities, quasi-judicial boards, appointed boards, and commissions. 
    Economic consideration means something of actual monetary value. 
    Elected official means any member of the Town of Davie Town Council and any municipal official as defined below. 
    Immediate family means either a father, mother, sister, brother, child, spouse or person residing in the same residential unit. 
    Legislation means any ordinance, resolution, or proposal of any kind which is the subject of present or prospective action by the town council. 
    Lobbying or lobbying activities means a communication, by any means, from a lobbyist to a covered individual regarding any item that will foreseeably be decided by a final decision-making authority, which communication seeks to influence, convince, or persuade the covered individual to support or oppose the item. 
    Lobbyist means a person who is retained, with or without compensation, for the purpose of lobbying, or a person who is employed by another person or entity, on a full-time or part-time basis, principally to lobby on behalf of that other person or entity. "Lobbyist" does not include a person who is: 
(1)  An elected official, employee, or appointee of Broward County or of any municipality within Broward County communicating in his or her official capacity. 
(2)  An individual who communicates on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of a person or entity employing the individual on a full-time or part-time basis, unless the individual is principally employed by that person or entity to lobby. 
(3)  Any employee, officer, or board member of a homeowners' association, condominium association, or neighborhood association when addressing, in his or her capacity as an employee, officer, or board member of such association, an issue impacting the association or its members; or 
(4)  Any employee, an officer, or a board member of a nonprofit public interest entity (e.g., Sierra Club, NAACP, ACLU) when addressing an issue impacting a constituent of that entity. 
    Municipal official means any individual serving as a member of the governing body of a municipality within Broward County or serving as a municipal mayor within Broward County. 
    Outside or concurrent employment means providing services for any person or entity, other than the elected official's governmental employer, in exchange for remuneration. 
    Person means any individual, business, corporation, association, partnership, governmental agency or other association recognized as a legal entity pursuant to Florida law. 
    Principal means the person for or upon whose behalf the lobbyist is lobbying. 
    Registration means providing the information required by this article, in writing, annually, and in supplements and amendments, as may be required. "Register" means to provide a registration in such a manner. 
    Relative shall have the meaning stated in F.S. § 112.3135. 
    Remuneration means the monetary payment received in return for services provided in connection with outside or concurrent employment, including salary, wages, commissions, tips, and bonuses. Remuneration does not include gifts, business expense reimbursements, paid training, direct employer contributions toward insurance, and other employee benefits(other than retirement plan contributions), and return of capital or payment of interest related to a return of one's capital contribution. 
    Town means the Town of Davie, Florida. 
    Vendor means a person or entity that is currently supplying any goods or services to the Town of Davie, that has supplied any goods or services to the Town of Davie within the current or prior two (2) town fiscal years, that has submitted a response to a currently open competitive bid solicitation, or has submitted a response to a competitive bid solicitation within the past two (2) fiscal years. 
(Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 2012-17, § 1, 8-15-12; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Sec. 2-58. - Required; information to be filed. 
(a)  Prior to engaging in lobbying activities, every lobbyist shall register with the town by filing with the town clerk the following information in writing: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the lobbyist is required on every amended, and supplemental registration. The "address" must be a physical address (e.g. not a post office box) where the lobbyist either resides or customarily does business. 
(2)  The nature and extent of any business, professional or familial relationship which the lobbyist, or any member of the lobbyist's immediate family, has had with any municipal official, or member of the immediate family of any municipal official within the period of time commencing twenty-four (24) months prior to registration and extending through the date of registration. No disclosure would be required of any such relationship existing prior to the effective date of this article. 
(3)  The nature and extent of any involvement, activity or assistance, whether paid or voluntary, by any lobbyist, or any member of the lobbyist's immediate family, with the current or the most recent campaign of any current elected municipal official, or current candidate for town council. 
(4)  Name, address and phone number of the lobbyist's principal(s), if known at the time of registration. The "address" must be a physical address (e.g. not a post office box) where the principal either resides or customarily does business. 
(5)  The general and specific matters upon which the lobbyist intends to lobby, if known at the time of registration. 
(b)  There shall be a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) charged by the town, for each principal represented and one-hundred dollars ($100.00) by each lobbyist. Such fee shall cover the cost of registering and maintaining a database of lobbyists as required by the Broward County Code of Ethics for Elected Officials. Said fee may be amended as needed by resolution. 
(c)  The registration information, and any supplement or amendment shall be filed in the town clerk's office. The registration must be signed by the lobbyist and attested to under penalty of perjury. The town clerk may approve a form of registration consistent with this article, which shall be used in all cases, except where unavailable. 
(d)  Registration will be yearly, running from October 1 to September 30 of each year, and shall be renewed for each year during which lobbying activities are to take place. Only one (1) annual registration form is required, per principal, per lobbyist. However, if any of the information required in the registration form is new or changed (for example, a new principal, as defined by this article, or a new specific subject of lobbying), then the lobbyist must supplement or amend the registration before additional lobbying. 
(e)  No more than three (3) days after the lobbyist meets with a Town of Davie elected official, the lobbyist is responsible for filling out and submitting the lobbyist log via the Town of Davie website. Failure to submit the lobbyist log shall result in an ethics violation by the lobbyist. The town clerk shall have the authority to periodically amend the lobbyist log as he/she seems necessary and to conform with county and state requirements. 
(1)  The lobbyist shall fill out the lobbyist log in its entirety. This includes the location of the meeting, the name of the people attending the meeting, the date of the meeting, the form of communication, the matter(s) discussed, and any additional information as listed on the lobbyist log form. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this article, no lobbyist shall be required to register only because the lobbyist has spoken at any public hearing or public meeting of the Town of Davie. 
(Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 2012-17, § 1, 8-15-12; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Sec. 2-59. - Conduct of principals and town council. 
(a)  Any principal who retains a lobbyist(s) in the town shall take reasonable measures to supervise and monitor its lobbyist(s) to ensure compliance with this article. 
(b)  Any councilmember who has actual knowledge and recollection of a lobbyist who fails to register as required in this article, or of a lobbyist who makes a material misrepresentation in registration shall disclose same in writing to the town clerk as soon as reasonably practical. Failure to make such disclosure shall subject the councilmember to a penalty as provided for in subsection 2-61(a). Nothing in this section shall require any inquiry by any councilmember to ascertain the compliance by any person with this article, nor does this section imply that any councilmember is required to remember all of his or her past dealings with lobbyists. 
(c)  No immediate family member or municipal office staff of a Town of Davie elected official shall lobby any covered individual. An immediate family member of an elected official may conduct business as a vendor or contractor with the Town of Davie where such activity is permissible under the laws of the State of Florida and Broward County. Any conduct in violation of this paragraph shall be deemed to provide a prohibited financial benefit to the elected official. 
(Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 2012-17, § 1, 8-15-12; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Sec. 2-60. - General construction. 
(a)  Examples and section headings are provided for clarity and for purposes of illustration only. Examples are not intended to imply that the illustration is the sole or exclusive possibility. 
(b)  All language and terms in this article shall be construed according to the definitions contained in the article. If there is no explicit definition in this article, then the language or term shall be construed according to the ordinary legal meaning in Florida; or if there is no ordinary legal meaning in Florida, then according to the ordinary and reasonable meaning to residents of the town. 
(c)  Lobbyist registrations must be true and accurate for matters of which the lobbyist has actual knowledge, or which the lobbyist may ascertain through reasonably diligent inquiry. 
(Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 2012-17, § 1, 8-15-12; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Sec. 2-61. - Penalties. 
(a)  A "penalty" in this article means the penalties specified in the Town of Davie Code of Ordinances, section 1-9 ("General penalty; continuing violations"); or in the event said section 1-9 is repealed or superseded, the general penalty specified by Town of Davie Code of Ordinances for violations of the Town of Davie Code of Ordinances. However, notwithstanding any language to the contrary in the general Code provisions for penalties, the maximum penalty for violation of this lobbyist ordinance shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). This article shall be enforced by issuance of a notice to appear in county court as authorized by F.S. § 162.22, as it may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  Any lobbyist who fails to register or willfully violates this article shall be subject to a penalty, as provided in subsection (a) above; and additionally shall be subject to imposition by the town council of a prohibition of further lobbying in the town for up to one (1) year. 
(c)  Any councilmember or principal who knowingly and willfully directs or permits a lobbyist to violate this article shall be subject to a penalty as provided in subsection 2-61(a). 
(Ord. No. 98-44, § 1, 10-21-98; Ord. No. 2012-17, § 1, 8-15-12; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Sec. 2-62. - Conduct of lobbyists outside of the town of Davie. 
(a)  If a lobbyist is found to have violated any state, county, or municipal ordinance pertaining to lobbying activities, that lobbyist shall be banned from lobbying within the Town of Davie until the lobbyist has been reinstated by the entity or agency that has revoked their lobbyist privileges. 
(Ord. No. 2017-006, § 2(Exh. A), 2-1-17) 
Secs. 2-63-2-70. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), adopted Apr. 20, 2011, amended Div. 1 to read as herein set out. Former Div. 1, §§ 2-71-2-77, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from 2002-9, § 3, adopted Mar. 19, 2002; Ord. No. 2002-012, § 1, adopted May 1, 2002; Ord. No. 2004-015, § 1, adopted Apr. 21, 2004; Ord. No. 2004-011, § 1, adopted May 5, 2004; Ord. No. 2005-007, § 1, adopted Apr. 20, 2005; Ord. No. 2006-007, § 1, adopted Feb. 15, 2006; Ord. No. 2006-011, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 3, 2006; Ord. No. 2006-027, § 2, adopted Dec. 6, 2006; Ord. No. 2007-008, § 2, adopted May 16, 2007; and Ord. No. 2009-014, § 1, adopted May 20, 2009. 

Sec. 2-71. - Intent and definitions. 
(a)  General intent. This article is intended to define the authority and rules of operation for advisory boards/committees. 
(b)  Boards/committees excluded. This article does not apply to any employee pension board, nor does it apply to boards/committees not specifically mentioned in the article which are entirely or predominantly composed of staff. 
(c)  [Reserved]. 
(d)  Resident meetings. Nothing in this article prohibits civic groups or groups of residents from meeting in town facilities in an unofficial capacity and giving advice to town government. The town shall have a policy of fostering and encouraging citizen participation in the process of government. 
(e)  Definitions. The following terms are defined for use in this article: 
    Advisory committee. A committee composed primarily of registered voters to provide advice to the town. All new committees, pursuant to the adoption of this section, shall be referred to as "committee." 
    Committee member. A member of any advisory committee established by section 2-73 or section 2-74, or a member of any committee established by this article. 
    Sunset. The time at which an advisory committee ceases to exist and all committee members are discharged from further duties. 
    Town council. Includes the mayor and councilmembers. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 2015-013, § 1, 5-20-15) 
Sec. 2-72. - Committee membership. 
(a)  Number of members. Except as otherwise provided, all advisory committees shall consist of two (2) members appointed by each councilmember and the mayor. 
(b)  Qualifications. The councilmember, mayor, or group appointing each committee member, shall determine the suitability of each person appointed to any advisory committee, provided that: 
(1)  Each committee member shall be a registered voter, except where a person is ineligible to be a registered voter solely due to their status as a minor or as a legal resident alien; and 
(2)  Each committee member must have an established domicile in the Town of Davie or be a Davie business owner with a business tax receipt (BTR) in good standing. Committee members may not engage in business transactions with the town. 
(3)  Each committee member shall be provided a handbook, prepared by the town clerk's office, which shall provide insight into the role and responsibilities of committee members. It shall be the responsibility of committee members to review the handbook and fully understand their role and responsibilities. 
(c)  Term. The term for a seat on a committee shall be two (2) years, unless otherwise noted in this article. If a vacancy occurs on a committee, the councilmember or mayor who has the right to make the appointment to that particular committee seat shall be entitled to name the successor for the unexpired term of that committee member's seat. A councilmember or the mayor can reappoint a person to a committee at the end of that person's term on a committee. 
    Any committee member may be removed for any reason by the councilmember (or that councilmember's successor), mayor, or the group which made the appointment. 
    The town council may remove a committee member for lack of attendance, misconduct, illegal acts or moral turpitude, or if it is determined that the appointee is no longer a town resident or Davie business owner. Any member that has been removed by the town council may not serve on a committee for a period of one (1) year. 
    A committee member who has three (3) consecutive unexcused absences or is absent fifty (50) percent or more of the meetings in any twelve-month period, is automatically dismissed from the committee. An unexcused absence is defined as any absence which was not excused at a prior meeting, or which occurred as a result of an illness or other unforeseen emergency. A motion and second, along with the accompanying affirmative vote shall be required to excuse the absence of a committee member. The mayor or councilmember may reappoint a member who has been dismissed as a result of unexcused absences, if they feel the absences were due to extenuating circumstances. The committee liaison or secretary shall be responsible for notifying the town clerk's office for placement of the vacancy on a future town council agenda. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2012-6, § 2(Exh. A), 4-18-12; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 2015-013, § 1, 5-20-15) 
Sec. 2-73. - Advisory committees. 
    Advisory committees are established by this article and continue until the term of the committee is sunset. The advisory committees include (but are not limited to): 
(a)  Budget advisory committee. 
(1)  There shall be five (5) members of the budget advisory committee. 
(2)  This committee reviews a variety of projects/items that may have significant financial impact on the town, with the budget and finance director. Additionally, council may direct the committee through the town administrator to review special areas of interest. 
(3)  Members shall have experience in a financial related occupation, or similar skills. 
(4)  Meetings will be held quarterly. 
(b)  Youth education and safety advisory committee. 
(1)  The committee's mission is to make recommendations to the town council regarding education, improving communications between schools and school populations, recommending projects for improving safety for school children, and advising the council on health, safety, and quality of life issues that affect students. 
(2)  Members shall, whenever possible, be versed in law enforcement, school instruction, education matters, child psychology, pediatric medicine, parenthood and grandparenthood. 
(3)  Meetings will be held bimonthly. 
(c)  Community redevelopment agency (governed by F.S. Ch. 163, pt. III and Chapter 12, Article XIII, Division 3). 
(d)  Agricultural and environmental advisory committee. 
(1)  There shall be ten (10) members of the agricultural and environmental advisory committee. 
(2)  This committee is created to advise the town council with regard to any and all matters affecting the agricultural community or the agricultural lifestyle of the town, as well as environmental protection, resource conservation and energy efficiency; including the development of goals and strategies, educational campaigns, and efforts to promote town accomplishments on these matters. 
(3)  Members, insofar as possible, shall have experience in agricultural and/or environmental matters, related occupations or other similar skills. 
(4)  Meetings will be held quarterly. 
(e)  [Reserved] . 
(f)  [Reserved]. 
(g)  [Reserved]. 
(h)  [Reserved]. 
(i)  Open space and recreation advisory committee. 
(1)  This committee is established to assist the town in the planning and development of open space. 
(2)  This committee also studies and makes recommendations concerning the development, operation and maintenance of all parks, playgrounds, and other recreational activities and facilities of the town. 
(3)  Meetings will be held quarterly. 
(j)  [Reserved]. 
(k)  Planning and zoning board (governed by Charter Section 9(C) and Chapter 2, Article V, Division 4). 
(1)  [Reserved] 
(m)  Senior citizen advisory committee. 
(1)  This committee makes recommendations to the town council and the town administrator for proposed activities, programs and opinions about issues that will address the lifestyle of elderly residents. 
(2)  Members shall be a minimum sixty (60) years of age. 
(n)  Site plan committee (governed by Chapter 2, Article V, Division 5). 
(o)  Unsafe Structures board (governed by Chapter 5, Article III). 
(p)  United Ranches preservation board (governed by annexation agreement). 
(1)  There shall be five (5) members of the United Ranches preservation board. 
(2)  Members will reside in the United Ranches area. 
(3)  Members shall be appointed every two (2) years by the governing body. 
(4)  This committee shall be responsible for issuing recommendations on zoning changes within the United Ranches area and shall meet as needed. 
(5)  Committee must meet at least once per year. 
(q)  Reports. Each committee shall submit an annual report by January 31st for the prior year to the town clerk's office for distribution to the town council and town administrator. Report shall detail Issues the committee is working on, committee recommendations, and accomplishments of the committee for the prior year. An oral presentation is not required unless requested by the town council. 
(r)  Adoption of fiscal year initiatives. Committees shall adopt initiatives for the new fiscal year by September 30th. The initiatives should be in line and consistent with the committee's mission. (Except: United Ranches preservation board, unsafe structures board, site plan committee, and planning and zoning board). 
(s)  Liaisons. Each advisory committee shall have a staff liaison assigned as directed by the town administrator or his/her designee. 
(t)  Special meetings. As directed by the town council or the town administrator, under special circumstances committees may meet, as needed, to address time sensitive issues such as budget discussions or special projects. Meetings shall be held monthly, bi-monthly, or quarterly unless otherwise noted in this article or determined by an affirmative vote of the committee members. 
(u)  Meeting notice. All meeting notices must be posted a minimum of forty-eight (48) hours prior to the meeting date. 
(v)  Quorum. Greater than fifty (50) percent of the total number of appointed committee members shall be required to be present to hold a meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 1375, § 1, 2-2-15) 
Sec. 2-74. - Advisory committees with a limited term of existence. 
(a)  The town council may, by resolution, create one (1) or more advisory committee with a limited term of existence. 
(b)  The resolution creating any advisory committee with a limited term of existence shall specify: 
(1)  The specific task(s) of the committee. 
(2)  The duration of the term of the committee, which shall not exceed one (1) year. 
(3)  The method of reporting required. 
(4)  Other matters as requested by the town council. 
(5)  Any special operating rules or instructions. 
(c)  Each advisory committee with a limited term of existence, in addition to the reporting requirements set forth in section 2-73, shall provide a final report of its activities to the town council. The report will include any matters specified in the resolution creating the advisory committee. 
(d)  The term of any advisory committee with a limited term of existence may, by resolution of the town council, be extended for an additional period of up to one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 1375, § 1, 2-2-15) 
Sec. 2-75. - Recording meetings and taking minutes. 
    The town administrator shall designate an employee, or other designee, to record meetings and take minutes. 
(1)  Staff members transcribing meetings, shall provide minutes to the board/committee within ten (10) days of the meeting. 
(2)  If vendor is contracted to attend and transcribe a meeting, minutes shall be provided to the town within five (5) days of the meeting. 
(3)  If vendor is contracted to transcribe a meeting, minutes shall be provided to the town within seven (7) working days of notification. 
(4)  Approved minutes must be provided to the town clerk's office within one (1) week of the committee's approval. Please refer to the Town of Davie Standard Operating Procedure of Meeting Minutes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 1375, § 1, 2-2-15) 
Sec. 2-76. - Sunset provisions. 
(a)  Upon review of the annual report, existing committees shall sunset unless renewed by resolution or ordinance by the town council. 
(b)  The following advisory boards/committees are not subject to sunset provisions: 
(1)  Community redevelopment agency. 
(2)  Planning and zoning board. 
(3)  Site plan committee. 
(4)  United Ranches preservation board. 
(5)  Unsafe structures board. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 1375, § 1, 2-2-15) 
Sec. 2-77. - Cancellation of meeting. 
(a)  Prior to a regularly scheduled committee meeting, the staff liaison, or his/her appointed designee is responsible for posting any meeting cancellation notices, when it has been determined that there are no business items for committee consideration. 
(b)  The staff liaison, or his/her designee, is responsible for posting any meeting cancellation when the meeting's start time has been delayed for over fifteen (15) minutes due to the lack of a quorum. 
(c)  As provided for in subsection 2-72(d) contained herein, where a committee member who is more than thirty (30) minutes late to a meeting of their committee, and whereas the meeting of that committee has been cancelled, due to, all or in part, of the committee member's tardiness, an absence shall be recorded against the subject committee member by the staff liaison. Such absence shall be considered grounds for removal pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, §2(Exh. A), 4-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 1, 6-5-13; Ord. No. 1375, § 1, 2-2-15) 
Secs. 2-78-2-80. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - PERSONNEL BOARD[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 87-7, § 1, adopted Jan. 7, 1987, amended Div. 3 of Art. V of Ch. 2 to read as herein set out. Prior to such amendment, the substantive provisions of Div. 3 consisted of §§ 2-116-2-123, and were derived from provisions presumably enacted during the 1985 codification and from §§ 2-21(a)-(c) and 2-28-2-30 of the town's 1964 Code. 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2.171 et seq.; fire department, § 7-21 et seq.; police, Ch. 19; utilities department, § 25-16 et seq. 

Sec. 2-116. - Created. 
    A personnel board is hereby created for the limited purpose of reviewing the discharge of the town's nonunion employees. 
(Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 1-7-87) 
Sec. 2-117. - Membership. 
    The personnel board shall consist of four (4) members; one member shall be an employee selected by the employee, one member shall be selected by the department head, one member shall be a personnel representative, and the final member, who shall serve as the chair, will be the town administrator's designee. 
(Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 1-7-87) 
Sec. 2-118. - Rules and regulations. 
    The personnel board is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations which shall not be in conflict with the provisions of this article to more effectively carry out the functions of the board. 
(Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 1-7-87) 
Sec. 2-119. - Jurisdiction and duties of personnel board. 
(a)  Any nonunion town employee who has been terminated shall have five (5) working days within which to file a written grievance form with the town clerk. Said grievance shall specify: 
(1)  The employee's date of initial employment; 
(2)  His job classification; 
(3)  The reasons given for termination; and 
(4)  The requested relief. 
Provided, however, that the personnel board shall not be permitted to review the discharge of probationary employees, and further, that the personnel board shall have no authority to hear any grievance which has not been timely filed. 
(b)  The personnel board shall hear the evidence covering the reasons for discharge as filed by the department head. The department head shall present such evidence as he may have in support of the reasons for discharge. Thereafter, such discharged employee who has filed a timely appeal with the board shall then present such evidence as he may wish to offer in his defense and the parties to the appeal, (i.e., the discharged employee and the department head) shall be entitled to present rebuttal testimony. The personnel board shall hear oral arguments following presentation of the evidence upon the request of either party. 
(c)  After the conclusion of the hearing, the personnel board shall deliberate. The personnel board shall affirm the employee's termination unless it finds, by a majority vote, that the department head's action was arbitrary and capricious, defined herein as having no factual basis whatsoever. All findings of the board shall be reduced to writing and transmitted to the parties within ten (10) working days. 
(Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 1-7-87) 
Sec. 2-120. - Authority of personnel board. 
(a)  The personnel board shall have the power to subpoena witnesses and to require the production of pertinent documents and to administer oaths. 
(b)  The town clerk or authorized deputies shall serve as clerk of the personnel board. 
(Ord. No. 87-7, § 1, 1-7-87) 
Secs. 2-121-2-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; floodplain management, § 12-541 et seq.; local improvements and assessments, Ch. 14; planning and development, Ch. 18; signs and advertising, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch.27. 

Sec. 2-136. - Created; membership. 
    A town planning and zoning board is hereby created and such board shall consist of five (5) members, who shall be residents of the town. 
(Code 1964, § 10C-1; Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 4-20-11) 
Sec. 2-137. - Appointment; terms. 
    Members of the planning and zoning board shall be appointed by the council by a three-fifths majority vote of such council. Each councilmember shall be entitled to exclusively nominate one (1) member of the board. After nomination by a councilmember, if the nominee fails to be appointed by a three-fifths majority vote of the council, then the nominating councilmember shall nominate another individual as a prospective member and shall be entitled to continue to nominate prospective members until a nominee is appointed by a three-fifths majority vote of such council. Such members shall hold office for terms of one (1) year commencing on the fourth Wednesday of May and, if subsequently reappointed, may succeed themselves in office. The Broward County school board may appoint one (1) non-voting member to the planning and zoning board for the purpose of attending those meetings at which the board will consider comprehensive plan amendments and rezonings that would, if approved, increase residential density on the property that is the subject of the application. 
(Code 1964, § 10C-1; Ord. No. 89-35, § 1, 9-20-89; Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 4-20-11) 
Sec. 2-138. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the planning and zoning board to consider all proposed zoning changes, plats and such other matters as may require planning and zoning board review as set forth in the Town Code. For each item requiring planning and zoning board review, the planning and zoning board shall make a recommendation to the town council. The planning and zoning board shall also serve as the local planning agency pursuant to F.S. § 163.3161 et seq., Local Government Comprehensive Planning Act of 1975. 
(Code 1964, § 10C-1; Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 4-20-11) 
Secs. 2-139-2-150. - Reserved.

(Code 1964, § 4-2.2(d)(2); Ord. No. 87-79, § 1, 7-1-87; Ord. No. 91-24, § 1, 5-1-91; Ord. No. 95-28, § 1, 7-5-95)

DIVISION 6. - PLAYGROUND AND RECREATION BOARD 

Sec. 2-154. - Establishment of playground and recreation board. 
    There is hereby created a board entitled "Playground and Recreation Board," which is deemed to be a playground and recreation board pursuant to Chapter 418, Part I, Florida Statutes. The playground and recreation board shall be comprised of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the mayor of the town and shall serve without compensation; provided, however, the initial playground and recreation board shall be comprised of the members of the town council of the town. Members of the playground and recreation board shall serve for a term of five (5) years and shall remain in, and exercise the powers of, office until their successors are appointed and qualified. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the members of the playground and recreation board first appointed shall be appointed for such terms so that the term of one member shall expire annually thereafter. Immediately after their appointment, the members of the playground and recreation board shall meet and organize by electing one of their members as president and electing such other officers as they deem necessary. Vacancies on the playground and recreation board occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled by the mayor only for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 88-45, § 1, 9-7-88) 
Sec. 2-155. - Responsibilities and powers of the playground and recreation board. 
(a)  The playground and recreation board shall be subject to all responsibilities of local authorities under Chapter 418, Part I, Florida Statutes. The playground and recreation board shall have the power to provide, establish, conduct and maintain a recreation system, including, but not limited to, the Green Space Network, and to exercise all powers of local authorities under Chapter 418, Part I, Florida Statutes; provided, however, the playground and recreation board shall have no power to issue bonds or to levy taxes. The powers of the playground and recreation board shall include, but not be limited to, the power to provide, maintain and conduct playgrounds, recreation centers and other recreational activities and to undertake the following: 
(1)  To dedicate and set apart for use as playgrounds and recreation centers and other recreation purposes any lands or buildings, or both, owned or leased by the town and not dedicated or devoted to another or inconsistent public use. 
(2)  To acquire or lease lands or buildings, or both, within or beyond the corporate limits of the town in such manner as may now or hereafter be authorized or provided by law for the acquisition of lands or buildings for public purposes, for playgrounds, recreation centers and other recreational purposes. 
(3)  To provide for the conduct, equipment and maintenance of land or buildings dedicated, set apart, acquired or leased for playgrounds, recreation centers and other recreational purposes, by making an appropriation from general town funds. 
(b)  The playground and recreation board may accept any grant or devise of real estate or any gift or bequest of money or other personal property or any donation to be applied, principal or income, for either temporary or permanent use for recreation purposes; provided, that if the acceptance thereof for such purposes will subject the town to additional expense for improvement, maintenance or renewal, the acceptance of any such grant or devise of real estate shall be first subject to the approval of the town council of the town. Money received for such purpose, unless otherwise provided by the terms of the gift or bequest, shall be deposited with the finance department of the town to the account of the playground and recreation board and the same shall be withdrawn and paid out by the board in the same manner as money appropriated for recreation purposes. 
(Ord. No. 88-45, § 1, 9-7-88) 
Sec. 2-156. - Powers of the town council of the town. 
    In connection with the establishment of a recreation system within the town, including, but not limited to, the Green Space Network, the town council of the town shall have the powers provided in Chapter 418, Part I, Florida Statutes, and other applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the power to undertake the following: 
(1)  To issue bonds pursuant to law and in conformity with the Constitution of the State of Florida, in the manner provided by law for the issuance of bonds for other purposes, for the purpose of acquiring lands or buildings for playgrounds, recreation centers and other recreational purposes for the equipment thereof. 
(2)  To annually levy and collect a tax designated as the "Playground and Recreation Tax" pursuant to, and in the manner provided in, Chapter 418, Part I, Florida Statutes, for the conduct and maintenance of the recreation system. 
(3)  To cooperate with any other municipality or county to jointly provide, establish, maintain and conduct a recreation system and acquire property for and establish and maintain playgrounds, recreation centers and other recreational facilities and activities, including, without limitation, entering into interlocal agreements relating thereto. 
(4)  To create and maintain such funds and accounts as may be necessary and appropriate to hold all taxes or monies received in connection with the establishment, maintenance and conduct of a recreation system within the town. 
(Ord. No. 85-45, § 1, 9-7-88) 
Sec. 2-157. - Payment of expenses and custody of funds. 
    The cost and expense of the establishment, maintenance and conduct of a recreation system within the town shall be paid out of taxes collected or money received for this purpose, and the playground and recreation board shall have the exclusive control of all monies collected or donated to the credit of the playground and recreation fund created by subsequent ordinance or resolution in connection with the recreation system. 
(Ord. No. 88-45, § 1, 9-7-88) 
Secs. 2-158-2-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Personnel board, § 2-116 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; code enforcement board, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; garbage and trash, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; landscaping, Ch. 12; floodplain management, § 12-541 et seq.; licenses and businesses regulations, Ch. 13; planning and development, Ch. 18; signs and advertising, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 22; utilities, Ch. 25; vegetation, Ch. 26; zoning, Ch. 27.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-171. - Right of entry. 
    Whenever any officer or employee of the town is required or authorized by the Charter, any state statute, the provisions of this Code, or any ordinance or resolution, or rules and regulations or orders issued thereunder, in order to carry out his duties thereunder, to enter any premises or vehicle for the purpose of making an inspection thereof or of anything therein contained or for the purpose of carrying out his duties, such officer or employee shall have the right to enter any such premises or vehicle at any reasonable time in pursuance of such duties. Such entry and inspection shall be made in a lawful manner. 
(Code 1964, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Inspection warrants, F.S. § 933.20. 
Sec. 2-172. - Restrictions on representation for compensation before the town by former officers or employees. 
    No appointed officer or employee of the Town of Davie shall, for a period of two (2) years following vacation of office or termination of employment, personally represent another person or entity for compensation before the Town of Davie except for the purposes of collective bargaining. 
(Ord. No. 2000-21, § 1, 6-21-00) 
Sec. 2-173. - Criminal history record checks for town employees, contracted personnel, volunteers, appointees and private contractors. 
(a)  F.S. § 166.0442 grants municipalities the authority to require state and national criminal screening for employment that is critical to security or public safety. 
(1)  All town employees, potential employees, appointees, volunteers, contracted personnel, and potential contracted personnel applying for employment or continuing employment or appointment of which are critical to security or public safety must undergo a level 2, as defined in F.S. § 435, state and national background check. This criminal history screening shall be submitted electronically and shall include fingerprinting so that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the Federal Bureau of Investigations can process the screening. The costs associated with the criminal history screening shall be paid for by the town. 
(2)  All private contractors and potential private contractors that are critical to security or public safety must undergo a level 2, as defined in F.S. § 435, state and national background check. This criminal history screening shall be submitted electronically and shall include fingerprinting so that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement and the Federal Bureau of Investigations can process the screening. The costs associated with the criminal history screening shall be paid by the private contractor. 
(Ord. No. O2018-016, § 2(Exh. A), 5-16-18) 
State Law reference- F.S. § 166.0442 
Secs. 2-174-2-185. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - OLD AGE AND SURVIVORS' INSURANCE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 7-21 et seq.; police, Ch.19. 

Sec. 2-201. - Federal benefits ended. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the town to extend effective as of June 1st, 1961, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law, nor excepted herein, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors' insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, and by F.S. Chapter 650; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in F.S. section 650.02, performed in the employ of the town by employees and officials thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 14-1) 
Sec. 2-202. - Agreement with state. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state division of retirement as state agency, for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of old age and survivors' insurance to the employees and officials of this town as provided in section 2-201 which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the town as are found by the state agency to be necessary and proper, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed on and after the 1st day of June, 1961. 
(Code 1964, § 14-2) 
Sec. 2-203. - Salary withholdings. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-201 hereof are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by the laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1964, § 14-3) 
Sec. 2-204. - Town contributions. 
    There shall be appropriated from available finds, derived from the town general fund, such amounts, at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the town as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1964, § 14-4) 
Sec. 2-205. - Records, reports and regulations. 
    The town shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the regulations of the state agency. 
(Code 1964, § 14-5) 
Sec. 2-206. - Adoption of federal act. 
    The town does hereby adopt the terms, conditions requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Code 1964, § 14-6) 
Sec. 2-207. - Custodian of fund; reporting agent. 
    The director of budget and finance is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the town, and the director of budget and finance is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 14-7) 
Cross reference- Duties of the town clerk, § 2-186. 
Secs. 2-208-2-225. - Reserved.
