ARTICLE VIII. - PURCHASING[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, adopted Feb. 4, 2015, amended Art. VIII to read as herein set out. Former Art. VIII, §§ 2-315-2-329, pertained to similar subject matter. 

Sec. 2-315. - Purchases-Not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars. 
    Purchases not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) may be effected without formal or informal bids. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2009-1, § 1, 1-7-09; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-316. - Purchases-Exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars but not exceeding twenty-five thousand dollars. 
    Purchases in amounts of over two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) but not exceeding twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) within the fiscal year may be effected without advertising for formal sealed bids, but at least three (3) informal bids shall be obtained if practicable. All purchases made through the informal bid process will require written unsealed bids including fax transmissions from prospective vendors and will be obtained by the Purchasing Division with the use of a specification prepared by the using department. In all instances, the Procurement Manager shall have the right to require adequate documentation to insure the bids are fairly acquired and that a competitive environment is maintained. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 96-3, § 1, 2-7-96; Ord. No. 97-41, § 1, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2003-003, § 1, 2-5-03; Ord. No. 2009-1, § 1, 1-7-09; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-317. - Purchases-In amounts over twenty-five thousand dollars. 
    Purchases exceeding twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall require newspaper advertising as prescribed by applicable ordinances or advertising by posting in two (2) conspicuous places in the town limits for formal sealed bids to be opened in public pursuant to applicable town ordinances and finance department regulations. Purchases shall be made from, or the contract awarded to, the lowest qualified responsive and responsible bidder: provided, however, that any and all bids may be rejected by the town council upon the vote of three (3) of its members. The town council shall approve such contracts or purchases by appropriate resolution. Town council approval is required for: a) any single transaction that exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), or b) multiple transactions with the same vendor where the anticipated expenditure will exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in any given fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 96-3, § 1, 2-7-96; Ord. No. 2003-003, § 1, 2-5-03; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-318. - Purchases-Purchases defined. 
    As used herein, the word "purchase" is defined to include contracts awarded for construction, alterations, repairs, maintenance, or services as well as contracts purchasing or realty. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-319. - Purchases-Professional services. 
    Competitive bidding shall not be required on contracting for professional services of accountants, dentists, lawyers, physicians, psychologists, veterinarians, or other such occupation which by reason of specialized training and expertise is generally recognized as a profession. The town will at all times comply with applicable state statutes regarding consultants competitive negotiations for services as defined by F.S. § 287.055. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 96-3, § 1, 2-7-96; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-320. - Purchases-Leases. 
    Leases in which the town is either lessee or lessor may be for such period as the town council may deem desirable. If it deems such necessary the Town Council may enter into lease purchase agreements. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-321. - Purchases-Bonding. 
    The town council may by resolution, require that successful bidders provide performance bonds, labor and material bonds, or other appropriate types of bonds. The town council may, by resolution, provide that in connection with any contract, a percentage of the contract amount be withheld for a period of thirty (30) days beyond the date the town finally accepts material, equipment, work or services provided under the terms of such contract. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-322. - Purchases-Joint procurement. 
    The town council may, by resolution, authorize participation by the Town in joint procurement of materials, work or services with other public corporations within the state. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-323. - Purchases-Council approval. 
    The town council's approval shall be required on all contracts for services in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). All expense contracts five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and under, including zero dollar ($0.00) contracts, can be handled administratively but are still subject to review by the town attorney. All expense contracts more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) must go to town council by resolution to authorize the mayor's signature. If the contract is a multi-year contract, the total value of the contract is the amount for all years of the contract for purposes of determining who has authority to sign the contract. (e.g. a three (3) year contract for two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per year would require the mayor's signature because the total value of the contract is six thousand dollars ($6,000.00)). 
(Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, 9-21-11; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-324. - Purchases-Additional purchase requirements and procedures. 
    The town council is hereby authorized to establish additional requirements in connection with purchases; provided that they are not inconsistent with any of the provisions herein. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, 9-21-11; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-325. - Purchases-Emergency purchases. 
    The town council may, upon proper showing, authorize emergency expenditures and dispense with the formal requirements for bidding therein. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-326. - Purchases-Alternative purchasing standards. 
    As an alternate for purchases governed by this section, the town council may comply and accepts bids in accordance with government purchasing standards as the same now exist or may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 88-70, § 1, 11-2-88; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-327. - Purchases-Purchasing from town employees. 
    The town shall not purchase any goods or services from any person who is actively employed by the Town of Davie or from any business or entity of which the employee or the employee's spouse or child is an agent, officer, partner, director or proprietor or in which they have a material interest or discretionary authority. Any such individual or business shall be disqualified from participating in any bidding activity for purchases by the town unless specifically authorized by action of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 92-8, § 1, 2-19-92; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Sec. 2-328. - Insurance. 
    Prior to its expiration date, each insurance program shall be reviewed as to reasonableness of coverage, cost effectiveness, and administrative efficiency, along with current market conditions. Upon completion of review, the town administrator will direct staff to renew, renegotiate, or competitively bid or negotiate the program. In any event, each insurance program shall be put through a competitive process at least every five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 97-41, § 2, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 2-329. - Local vendor preference definitions. 
    Local Davie Vendor. A "local Davie vendor" shall mean a person or business entity which has maintained a permanent place of business with full-time employees within the town limits for a minimum of six (6) months prior to the date of issuance of a bid or proposal solicitation. The permanent place of business may not be a post office box or a residence. The business location must actually distribute goods or services from that location. In addition, the business must have a current business tax receipt from the Town of Davie and have an address that the U.S. Postal Service recognizes as being a Davie address to be eligible. 
    Local Broward County Vendor. A "local Davie vendor" shall mean a person or business entity which has maintained a permanent place of business with full-time employees within the Broward County limits for a minimum of six (6) months prior to the date of issuance of a bid or proposal solicitation. The permanent place of business may not be a post office box or a residence. The business location must actually distribute goods or services from that location. In addition, the business must have a current business tax receipt from the Broward County or the city within Broward County where the business resides and have an address that the U.S. Postal Service recognizes as being a Broward County address to be eligible. 
    Bid. A bid shall be any competitive solicitation by specification officially posted by the Town of Davie Purchasing staff on the town's website where the award is determined by price. 
    Proposal. A proposal shall be any competitive solicitation by request for proposal (RFP) officially posted by the Town of Davie purchasing staff on the town's website where the award is determined by qualifications. 
Process 
(1)  Competitive bid. For bid evaluation purposes, vendors that meet the definition of "local Davie vendor" as detailed above shall be given a five (5) percent evaluation credit. This shall mean that if a "local Davie vendor" submits a bid/quote that is within five (5) percent of the lowest price submitted by any vendor, the "local Davie vendor" shall have an option to submit another bid which is at least one (1) percent lower than the lowest responsive bid/quote. If the "local Davie vendor" submits a bid which is at least one (1) percent lower than that lowest responsive bid/quote, then the award will go to the "local Davie vendor." If not, the award will be made to the vendor that submits the lowest responsive bid/quote. If the lowest responsive and responsible bidder is a "local Davie vendor," the award will be made to that vendor and no other bidders will be given an opportunity to submit additional bids as described herein. 
For bid evaluation purposes, vendors that meet the definition of "local Broward County vendor" as detailed above shall be given a two and one-half (2.5) percent evaluation credit. This shall mean that if a "local Broward County vendor" submits a bid/quote that is within two and one-half (2.5) percent of the lowest price submitted by any vendor, the "local Broward County vendor" shall have an option to submit another bid which is at least one (1) percent lower than the lowest responsive bid/quote. If the "local Broward County vendor" submits a bid which is at least one (1) percent lower than that lowest responsive bid/quote, then the award will go to the "local Broward County vendor." If not, the award will be made to the vendor that submits the lowest responsive bid/quote. If the lowest responsive and responsible bidder is a "local Davie vendor", the award will be made to that vendor and no other bidders will be given an opportunity to submit additional bids as described herein. 
If there is a "local Davie vendor" and a "local Broward County vendor" participating in the same bid solicitation and both vendors qualify to submit a second bid as detailed above, the "local Davie vendor" will be given first option. If the "local Davie vendor" cannot beat the lowest bid received by at least one (1) percent, an opportunity will be given to the "local Broward County vendor." If the "local Broward County vendor" cannot beat the lowest bid by at least one (1) percent, then the bid will be awarded to the lowest bidder regardless of geographic location of the business. 
If multiple "local Davie vendors" submit bids/quotes which are within five (5) percent of the lowest bid/quote, then all vendors will be asked to submit a "best and final offer (BAFO)." The award will be made to the "local Davie vendor" submitting the lowest BAFO providing that that BAFO is at least one (1) percent lower than the lowest bid/quote received in the original solicitation. If no "local Davie vendor" can beat the lowest bid/quote by at least one (1) percent, then the process will be repeated with all "local Broward County vendors" who have submitted a bid/quote which is within two and one-half (2.5) percent of the lowest bid/quote. If no "local Davie vendor" and no "local Broward County vendor" can submit a BAFO that is at least one (1) percent lower than the lowest bid/quote submitted in the original solicitation, the award will be made to the lowest responsive bidder regardless of geographic location of the business. 
(b)  Competitive proposal. For evaluation purposes, "local Davie vendor" and "local Broward County vendor" shall be a criterion for award in any request for proposal unless specifically exempted by the town administrator or the town council. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
1.  No "local vendor" preference will be included in any competitive solicitation where the town is the lead agency for the Southeast Florida Cooperative Purchasing Group. 
2.  Utilization of a state or other agency contract. 
3.  State or Federal law prohibits the use of local preference. 
4.  The work is funded in whole or in part by a governmental entity where the laws, rules, regulations or policies prohibit the use of local preferences. 
5.  Sole source or single source purchases. 
6.  The "local vendor" is either non-responsive or non-responsible. 
7.  All bids submitted exceed the budget amount for the project. 
8.  Emergency purchases. 
9.  The town administrator and/or the town council may exempt any competitive solicitation from the local vendor preference. 
(Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, 9-21-11; Ord. No. 2015-003, § 1, 2-4-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-32, § 1, adopted Sept. 21, 2011, enacted provisions to be included herein as § 2-328. Inasmuch as there were already provisions designated as such, said provisions have been redesignated as § 2-329 at the discretion of the editor.

Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; garbage and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; the keeping of animals which make loud and continuous noises prohibited, § 15-4(5); streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, F.S. Ch. 828; damage by dogs, F.S. Ch. 67; livestock running at large, F.S. § 588.12 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Restrictions on riding or driving equines or bovines. 
(a)  As used in this section, animal shall mean bovine animals, male and female, singular and plural. 
(b)  No person shall ride or lead an animal, as herein defined: 
(1)  On any sidewalk, except when using the school crosswalk bridge or 61st Avenue bridge; 
(2)  Through any service station; 
(3)  Through any shopping center; 
(4)  Upon private property without the prior consent or authorization of the property owner; 
(5)  On or along a street or roadway other than on the left side of the street or roadway facing approaching traffic, except where bridle paths are provided; 
(6)  In other than single file, except on designated bridle paths; 
(7)  Between sunset and sunrise unless the animal, and the person riding or leading it, each bears a reflector of such size and characteristics and so maintained as to be readily visible at nighttime from all distances within five hundred feet to fifty feet from the animal when in front of laWful upper beams of motor vehicle headlamps. 
(c)  Animals may cross 64th Avenue between S.W. 39th Street and S.W. 45th Street only at marked school or animal crossings and signal lights. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-1(a)-(d)) 
Sec. 4-2. - Group of riders. 
    A person at least eighteen (18) years of age must be placed in charge of any organized group of riders on any designated bridle path or public way, from any riding academy, stable, club or similar establishment. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-1(e)) 
Sec. 4-3. - Traffic regulations to apply to riding animals. 
    Every person riding an animal in the town shall be subject to the provisions of the traffic ordinances and regulations of the town, except those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-1) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 4-4. - Exceptions. 
    The police mounted patrol, as well as any mounted patrol so authorized by the chief of police (i.e. search and rescue, etc.), are excluded from this article. 
Sec. 4-5. - Safety helmet required for riding horses and other equine animals. 
(a)  It is the intent of the Town of Davie by enacting and codifying this section into its Code of Ordinances, to further promote the safety, health and welfare of its residents, and to regulate traffic and other lawful activities within defined public areas. 
(b)  After April 1, 2000, an equine animal rider who is under sixteen (16) years of age must wear a helmet that meets the American Society of Testing and Materials (ASTM) standards (or any other nationally recognized standard for equine helmets adopted by the Town of Davie Police Department through its administrative procedures) which is properly fitted and fastened securely upon the rider's head by a strap, when riding in a public area. This requirement applies regardless of whether a rider is controlling the equine animal. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision in this section to the contrary, the term "equine animal" shall mean a horse, pony, mule or donkey. The term "public area" as used within this subsection shall mean: 
i.  All areas within the town where the Town of Davie enjoys original jurisdiction to regulate traffic pursuant to the State Uniform Traffic Control Laws; 
ii.  All equestrian trails, recreational trails, active and passive parks, open space preserves, school sites, water control district properties and other areas within the town where equestrian activities occur or are planned; and 
iii.  Any and all other publicly owned or controlled property. 
(d)  After June 1, 2000, no parent of any person under sixteen (16) years of age, nor any guardian of any ward who is under sixteen (16) years of age may authorize or knowingly permit any such minor person or ward to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(e)  After June 1, 2000, no person may knowingly rent or lease any equine animal to be ridden by a person who is under sixteen (16) years of age unless the prospective rider possesses a helmet meeting the requirements of subsection (b) above or the lessor provides a helmet meeting such requirements for the prospective rider to wear. 
(f)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided by Florida law. Enforcement officers shall utilize the Broward County Teen Court when deemed appropriate for enforcement of this section. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section to the contrary, any minor rider not wearing a helmet meeting the requirements of subsection (b) above, who is then presently engaged in an emergency situation involving the police officers, firefighters, paramedics and/or any other public safety officials, or in such instance that would typically be construed to constitute such an emergency situation, despite the present absence of such public safety officers, shall not constitute a violation of this section. 
(h)  This section does not apply to equine riders when such riders are competing or performing during a show or event in which they are registered as participants and where the town issues an exclusive license or permit for the public property used, which license or permit shall include requirements for insurance, indemnities, and bonds. 
(Ord. No. 2000-18, § 1, 6-7-00) 
Sec. 4-6. - Equine Protection Act. 
(a)  In accordance with F.S. § 828.125, as may be amended from time to time, any person who willfully and unlawfully, by any means whatsoever, kills, maims, mutilates, or causes great bodily harm or permanent disability, to any animal of the genus Equus (horse) commits a violation of the town's Code. 
(b)  In accordance with F.S. § 500.451, as may be amended from time, it shall be a violation of the town's Code to transport, distribute, sell, purchase, or possess horse meat for human consumption, unless in strict accordance with law. 
(c)  A violation of this section presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, and welfare. The town has found that a violation of this section causes irreparable or irreversible harm, and as such, a violation of this section shall be prosecuted to the fullest extent and in accordance with the highest civil penalties and maximum sentence afforded by law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1, § 2, 1-2-13) 
Sec. 4-7. - Town of Davie Bird Sanctuary and Bird Rookery Protection Act. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Bird rookery means a town designated colony of breeding birds most commonly applied to the nesting place of birds. 
    Bird sanctuary means a town designated place of refuge or safety intended for birds. 
(b)  Town designated bird sanctuary. 
(1)  The town hereby declares all territory within the municipal limits of the Town of Davie to be a bird sanctuary. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the Town of Davie to hunt, wound, injure, kill, take, capture, ensnare, net, trap, or in any other manner molest any bird, bird nest, or bird eggs. Birds and bird eggs may only be removed after prior authorization is granted pursuant to the procedure outlined in section 4-7 (b)(3) of this ordinance. Nonnative species may not be released elsewhere but may be euthanized in a humane manner. 
(3)  In order to remove nuisance birds within the Town of Davie, prior authorization shall be obtained from the Code Compliance Official or his/her designee, to trap or remove birds, or bird eggs, after a determination that said birds, and/or their eggs, are a nuisance. Upon the determination of the existence of a nuisance, said birds and/or eggs may be removed. 
(4)  Any unauthorized acts or inhumane treatment of birds and/or their eggs that are found to have occurred shall be subject to the penalties found herein. 
(5)  These applicable rules and regulations may be posted at sites upon signage approved by the town administrator or other designated town official. 
(c)  Town designated bird rookery. 
(1)  The town hereby declares the Sunny Lake Bird Sanctuary a bird rookery. 
(2)  All rules and regulations stated in 4-7(b) shall also be applied to bird rookeries. 
(d)  Fishing in bird rookeries. 
(1)  Fishing may be permitted only in specially designated areas established and identified by the town with posted signage in a town designated bird rookery. 
(2)  In the Sunny Lake Bird Sanctuary and Rookery, fishing is only allowed in the western half of the lake which is designated by signage. 
(e)  Additional bird rookery rules. 
(1)  Dogs and cats are not permitted to roam freely in any town designated bird rookery and shall be maintained upon a leash which is under the control of the owner/responsible person at all times. Dogs or cats shall be removed by the owner/responsible person if they cause any nuisance-like disturbances within the lands of a town designated bird rookery, or be subject to a violation notice. 
(2)  It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to operate, permit or cause to be operated, any boat, watercraft or ATV which shall be powered or propelled by any engine, motor or other mechanical device in or near any waterway within the boundaries of a town designated bird rookery that contains any waterway, canal, or body of water. 
(3)  Canoes, kayaks, sailboats and similar non-motor driven watercraft and bicycles may be operated unless restrictions are posted with appropriate signage in designated areas in any town designated bird rookery. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person in violation of this ordinance shall be subject to prosecution as determined by the Town of Davie which may include a notice to appear, a civil citation, or a notice of violation that schedules their appearance before the town code enforcement special magistrate or a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2014-9, § 1, 3-19-14; Ord. No. 2016-024, § 2(Exh. A), 9-7-16) 
State Law reference- F.S. § 828.27 
Secs. 4-8-4-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WILD ANIMALS 

Sec. 4-21. - Defined. 
    The phrase "wild animals" is used as a term to indicate animals and reptiles of a species not usually domesticated in the United States. Such phrase does not refer to the comparative docility or familiarity with man or any pet animal, nor does such phrase refer to pets incidentally found in and about homes such as dogs, cats, gerbils, rabbits, turtles, small nonpoisonous lizards and the like. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-22. - Keeping of certain animals restricted. 
    No person shall keep, harbor, maintain or permit to be kept, harbored or maintained, within the town any animal, reptile or fowl which by its nature is wild, untamed and not domesticated and which would ultimately constitute a threat to the safety, health or well being of the citizens of the town. This section shall not apply to parks, zoos, pet shops, medical or scientific institutions or other places licensed for the showing or keeping of wild animals or reptiles. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-2) 
Sec. 4-23. - Permit required to keep wild animal. 
    It shall be a necessary prerequisite to the keeping or harboring of any wild animal as defined herein that the individual or person shall first obtain a permit from the State of Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission as prescribed by F.S. section 372.921. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-4) 
Secs. 4-24-4-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), adopted April 4, 2018, renamed art. III from "livestock running at large" to "livestock." 

Sec. 4-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words when used in this article shall have the meaning ascribed herein unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Animal shall mean any horse, pony, mule, cow, bull, steer, ox, heifer, calf, swine, ostrich, emu, rhea, sheep and goat, both domesticated and wild, male and female, singular and plural. 
    At large shall mean off the premises of the owner or custodian of the animal, and not under the immediate control of the owner or custodian. 
    Permit shall mean to suffer, allow, consent, let; to give leave or license; to acquiesce, by failure to prevent, or to expressly assent or agree to the doing of an act prohibited. 
    Shelter shall mean the operation of the person or firm designated by the town to pick up and board any animal found at large. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-12; Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-42. - Certain animals declared a nuisance. 
    No person owning or having in his custody animals as herein defined shall permit them to go at large to the injury or annoyance of others, nor shall such animal be permitted at large upon the streets or public ways of the town. Such action is declared to be a nuisance and dangerous to the public health and safety. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-13) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 4-43. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Any person finding any animal upon his property shall notify the police department and may remove the animal to an animal shelter. 
(b)  The town police department may impound the animal. If the town impounds the animal, reasonable effort shall be made to locate the owner. 
(c)  Any police officer or other person designated by the town for such purpose is authorized to capture and impound any animal found at large. Any police officer or other person designated by the town may issue a code violation to the owner for their animal being "at large." 
(Code 1964, § 3A-14; Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), adopted April 4, 2018, renamed § 4-43 from "impoundment generally; warrant of arrest for owner or custodian" to "impoundment." 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 19. 
Sec. 4-44. - Notice of impoundment and sale. 
(a)  Upon the impounding of any animal the chief of police shall forthwith serve written notice upon the owner, advising such owner of the location or place where the animal is being held and impounded, the amount due by reason of such impounding, and that unless such animal be redeemed within five (5) days from date thereof that the same shall be offered for sale. 
(b)  If the owner of such animal is unknown or cannot be found, service upon the owner shall be obtained by publishing a notice two (2) times, consecutively, in a newspaper or general circulation where the animal is impounded (Sundays and holidays excluded) and by posting in two (2) conspicuous places in the town limits. 
(c)  Unless the impounded animal is redeemed within three (3) days from the date of last publication of notice, the chief of police shall forthwith give notice of sale thereof which shall be held not less than five (5) days nor more than ten (10) days (excluding Sundays and holidays) from the first publication of the notice of sale. The notice of sale shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the town (excluding Sundays and holidays) and by posting a copy of such notice at two (2) conspicuous places in the town limits. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-15; Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-45. - Fees and costs. 
    The owner or custodian who redeems an animal will pay a pick-up fee to the police department in accordance with the following schedule: 
Fee 
Call out charge ..... $ 275.00 
Pick up charge ..... 30.00 
Each additional animal ..... 15.00 
Impounding charge (per day, per head) shall not exceed ..... 200.00 
(Code 1964, § 3A-16; Ord. No. 83-6, § 1, 2-16-83; Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-46. - Agreements to carry out terms of article. 
    The mayor is instructed to enter into the necessary agreement with animal hospitals, shelters and farms to carry out the terms of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 3A-17) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 4-47. - Manner of keeping. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person keeping or caring for an animal to fail to provide: 
(1)  Clean, sanitary, safe, and humane conditions; and 
(2)  Sufficient quantities of appropriate food daily; and 
(3)  Proper air ventilation and circulation; and 
(4)  Adequate quantities of visible, clean, and fresh water available at all times; and 
(5)  Medical attention or necessary veterinary care when sick, diseased, or injured. Upon request of the town designee, written proof of medical attention or veterinary care must be provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person keeping an animal to fail to provide shelter and/or adequate shade for that animal. Outdoor shelter must be of sound construction and provide adequate protection from rain, wind, and sun. The following elements shall be provided as essential components of shelter: 
(1)  Clean and appropriate bedding material, per the Florida Department of Environmental Protection or the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services best management practices 
(2)  Sufficient space for each animal to comfortably stand up, sit down, lie down, and turn around in the shelter, without touching the top or sides of the shelter. If the shelter is used for more than one (1) animal at the same time, it must provide enough space for both animals to comfortably stand up, sit down, lie down, and turn around simultaneously. 
(3)  All areas where the animals are kept must be cleaned and the fecal matter disposed of according to the best management practices set forth by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection or the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services. 
(Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-48. - Treatment of livestock. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to beat, mistreat, or intentionally harm an animal. 
(Ord. No. O2018-012, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Secs. 4-49-4-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 99-2, adopted January 20, 1999, amended Art. IV to read as herein set out. Prior to such amendment, Art. IV consisted of §§ 4-61-4-65, which contained similar provisions and derived from §§ 3A-29-3A-33 of the 1964 Code. 

Sec. 4-61. - Definitions. 
    [The following terms, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed herein unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    At large shall be intended to mean a dog not: 
(1)  Under the physical control of a responsible person, by means of a leash, cord, or chain; or 
(2)  In the physical presence of the owner or person in custody of the dog; or 
(3)  Confined to the real property of its owners by means of a fence constructed in a manner which serves to keep the dog confined to the property. 
"At large" shall not include dogs actually working livestock, locating or retrieving wild game in season for a licensed hunter, or a dog being trained to do so: or an animal being exercised while under the supervision of the owner or the owner's designee. 
    Attack shall mean the aggressive biting, by the teeth or the fangs, of a human or another animal which causes an injury. 
    Dog shall mean both male and female canines. 
    Enclosure shall mean that the dog is securely confined indoors or within a fence sufficient to keep the dog confined. 
    Excessive noise shall mean noise produced by a dog which is so loud and continuous as to disturb the peace and quiet of a neighbor, to include, but not [be] limited to, disturbing a neighbor's sleep or rest or the peaceful enjoyment of his property. 
    Harboring shall mean the act of keeping and caring for an animal, or the providing of premises to which the dog returns for food, shelter, or care for a period of at least forty-eight (48) hours. 
    Owner shall mean any person or persons, firm, association or corporation who owns, keeps, harbors or controls a dog. The knowledge and acts of agents and employees of corporations in regard to dogs transported, owned, employed by or in the custody of a corporation shall be held to be the knowledge and act of such corporation. If the owner is a minor as defined by statute, the minor's parent(s) or legal guardian shall be the owner for the purposes of this article. 
    Vicious dog shall mean any dog that, according to the records of the division or other animal control or law enforcement authority: 
(1)  Has, when unprovoked, approached any person in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places, provided that such action is attested to in a sworn statement by one (1) or more persons and dutifully investigated by an officer; or 
(2)  Has more than once, when unprovoked, severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property; or 
(3)  Has, when unprovoked, aggressively bitten, attacked, or endangered or has inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property; or 
(4)  Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of a dog fight or is a dog training for dog fighting. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99; Ord. No. 2002-19, § 1, 6-19-02; Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-62. - License and rabies vaccination. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep or harbor any dog within the town unless such dog is licensed and has been vaccinated with a rabies vaccine approved by the United States Department of Agriculture and administered by a veterinarian. 
(b)  Every owner is required to see that the tag is securely fastened to the dog's chain, collar or harness. The tag must be worn by the dog at all times, unless the dog, accompanied by owner, is engaged in a sport where a collar, chain or harness might endanger the dog's safety. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99; Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-63. - Running at large prohibited, declared nuisance. 
(a)  Any dog running at large within the town limits is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  Any dog, the ownership of which cannot be established, found running at large within the town limits and creating a public nuisance shall be impounded by the town and transferred to an animal shelter. 
(c)  The owner of any dog found running at large shall be guilty of a violation and may be prosecuted using the town's discretionary authority as follows: 
(1)  A municipal ordinance violation of this Code section in the Broward County court system to be punished as provided for in town code section 4-68; 
(2)  A town code violation of this Code section may be brought before the town's code enforcement special magistrate and punished as provided for in F.S. ch. 162.; 
(3)  In any prosecution brought under this section, it shall not be necessary for the town to allege or prove knowledge or neglect on the part of any accused person. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99; Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-63.1. - Dog attack. 
    It shall be unlawful for a dog to attack or bite another animal or human being, without provocation. 
(Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-64. - Vicious dogs. 
(a)  The owner of a vicious dog shall confine the dog in an enclosure and the owner shall not take the dog out of the enclosure unless the dog is securely muzzled and under the physical control of the owner by means of a leash, cord or chain. 
(b)  It is prohibited for a vicious dog to run at large within the town limits. Any vicious dog running at large within the town limits is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(c)  Any vicious dog found running at large shall be impounded and shall not be released except upon payment of any licensing fees due, costs and charges incurred for impounding and maintenance of the dog, and the owner provides written documentary evidence to the town that the dog shall remain in an enclosure thereafter. If any vicious dog found running at large cannot be safely impounded, the police may take any action to stop the vicious dog from injuring themselves or other persons or animals. 
(d)  The owner of any vicious dog found running at large shall be guilty of a violation and shall be punished as provided in section 4-68. In any prosecution brought under this section, it shall not be necessary for the town to allege or prove knowledge or neglect on the part of any accused person. 
(e)  No person shall own, keep or harbor a vicious dog without having a valid vicious dog license, pursuant to the Broward County Code of Ordinances, sections 4-12(f) and (g), as they may be amended from time to time. 
(f)  The owner of any vicious dog found running at large shall also be responsible to provide written documentary evidence to the town that the dog shall remain in an enclosure. 
(g)  The owner of any vicious dog found running at large shall be guilty of a violation and may be prosecuted using the town's discretionary authority as follows: 
(1)  A municipal ordinance violation of this Code section in the Broward County court system to be punished as provided for in town code section 4-68; 
(2)  A town code violation of this Code section may be brought before the town's code enforcement special magistrate and punished as provided for in F.S. ch. 162; 
(3)  In any prosecution brought under this section, it shall not be necessary for the town to allege or prove knowledge or neglect on the part of any accused person. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99; Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-65. - Leashing. 
    All dogs shall be kept secured by a leash or otherwise under the control of an owner or responsible person, or within the real property limits of the owners. A waiver to this requirement for a specific time and place may be obtained from the town for such activities as off-lead training, obedience matches and trials. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99) 
Sec. 4-65.1. - Tethering and basic animal care. 
(a)  No person shall tether, fasten, chain, tie, or restrain a dog, or cause a dog to be tethered, fastened, chained, tied, or restrained, to a dog house, tree, fence, or any other stationary object; rather, a tethered dog shall be tethered only on a running line, pulley, trolley system, or spiral stake, whereby the tether is connected to the dog by a buckle-type collar or a body harness constructed of nylon, leather, or similar material specifically designed to be used for a dog. The tether shall be at least five (5) times the length of the dog's body, as measured from the tip of the nose to the base of the tail: shall terminate at both ends with a swivel: shall not weigh more than one-eighth (?th) of the dog's weight; and shall be maintained free of tangles. The running line, pulley, or trolley system shall be at least fifteen (15) feet in length and no higher than seven (7) feet above the ground. 
(b)  A tethered dog must have convenient access to food, visibly clean water, and shade. Adequate protection from the elements shall be provided at all times. A tethered dog shall be tethered in such a manner as to prevent injury, strangulation, or entanglement. No dog shall be tethered in a location in which the tether would allow such dog to reach a potentially dangerous object or area, including, but not limited to, a window sill, edge of a pool or canal, fence, porch, tree, post, terrace railing, or other object or area that poses a substantial risk of injury or strangulation to such dog if such dog jumps over, goes into, or goes around the object or area. No dog shall be tethered in an area where it may be approached by and attacked by other dogs or animals or people, without the chance to escape to a protected area such as a dog house. No dog shall be tethered outdoors during extreme temperatures or severe inclement weather, nor shall a dog be tethered unless the owner, caretaker, or other responsible party is located at all times within the area where the dog is located, so as to be able to observe and hear and attend to the dog if necessary. 
(c)  Choke-type collars or prong/pinch-type collars shall be permitted to be used only while a dog is under a handler's direct control on a leash. Heavy chains, cords, wires, or any other material not commonly intended to be used as a dog collar shall not be used as a restraint, a tether, or a substitute for a dog collar. 
(Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-65.2. - Cruelty to animals. 
    Any person who beats, cruelly ill-treats, torments, overloads, overworks, fails to provide sanitary living conditions, starves, fails to provide reasonable medical care for illness or injury, tethers a dog in violation of section 4-65.1, hoards animals, uses an animal for the purposes of dog fighting, or otherwise abuses an animal or intentionally causes such animal to be mutilated or inhumanely killed, or causes the same to be done, or otherwise treats an animal in a cruel or inhumane manner, shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-65.3. - Manner of keeping. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person keeping or caring for a dog to fail to provide: 
(1)  Clean, sanitary, safe, and humane conditions; and 
(2)  Sufficient quantities of appropriate food daily; and 
(3)  Proper air ventilation and circulation; and 
(4)  Adequate quantities of visible, clean, and fresh water available at all times; and 
(5)  Medical attention or necessary veterinary care when sick, diseased, or injured. Upon request of the town designee, written proof of medical attention or veterinary care must be provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person keeping a dog to fail to provide shelter and/or adequate shade for that dog. Outdoor shelter must be of sound construction and provide adequate protection from rain, wind, sun, and all elements at all times. The following elements shall be provided as essential components of shelter: 
(1)  Clean and dry bedding material. 
(2)  Sufficient space for each dog to comfortably stand up, sit down, lie down, and turn around in the shelter, without touching the top or sides of the shelter. If the shelter is used for more than one (1) dog at the same time, it must provide enough space for both dogs to comfortably stand up, sit down, lie down, and turn around simultaneously. 
(3)  A solid weatherproof roof, a solid sanitary floor, and adequate ventilation. 
(4)  All areas where the dogs are kept must be cleaned and the fecal matter disposed of in a sealed trash receptacle so as not to attract insects or rodents, become unsightly, or cause objectionable odor. 
(c)  Any dog weighing twenty (20) pounds or less that is maintained outdoors for all or part of the day in a fenced yard or other type of enclosure shall be provided a minimum of one hundred (100) square feet of open space. Any dog weighing more than twenty (20) pounds that is maintained outdoors for all or part of the day in a fenced yard or other type of enclosure shall be provided a minimum of two hundred (200) square feet of open space. An additional forty (40) square feet shall be required for each additional dog kept in the same enclosed area. The enclosed area shall be large enough to provide each dog sufficient shelter within the required open space. Any enclosed area where a dog is confined shall be kept free of objects that may injure the dog. Dogs shall not be maintained outdoors during periods of extreme weather including, but not limited to, hurricanes, tropical storms, and tornados. 
(Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-66. - Excessive noise. 
    It is prohibited for a dog to make excessive noise that disturbs a neighbor within the town limits. A neighbor shall mean any individual residing within one hundred (100) yards of the property upon which the dog is owned, kept or harbored. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99) 
Sec. 4-67. - Owner's duty when dog bites a human or is bitten by another animal. 
(a)  If a dog bites any human being and the owner of the dog provides proof that the dog has been vaccinated for rabies during the previous twelve-month period, the owner of such animal shall confine the animal at home within the dwelling place or secure enclosure on the premises for a period of ten (10) days, or in the alternative, may confine the animal at a veterinary hospital, approved boarding facility or county animal shelter for that period. 
(b)  If a dog bites any human being and the owner of the dog is unable to provide proof that the dog has been vaccinated for rabies during the previous twelve-month period, a law enforcement officer or an animal control officer is authorized to take the animal to a veterinary hospital, approved boarding facility or county animal shelter for a period of ten (10) days for confinement and the owner of the dog shall be responsible for all costs associated with the confinement including any necessary vaccinations. In the event the owner of the dog provides proof of vaccination within the ten (10) day period of confinement, the dog may be released to the owner provided that the owner agrees to confine the animal at home within the dwelling place or secure enclosure on the premises for the remainder of the prescribed confinement period. 
(c)  In the event an owner of a dog fails or refuses to take possession of its dog from a veterinary hospital, approved boarding facility, or county animal shelter after the period of confinement has expired, the veterinary hospital, approved boarding facility, or county animal shelter may humanely destroy the dog in accordance with its practices, regulations and/or procedures. 
(d)  If any dog is bitten by an animal diagnosed by a veterinarian as rabid, the dog shall be dealt with in accordance with the Florida Department of Health Rules and Regulations. If any dog is bitten by an animal and the other animal is not available for rabies examination, or if the dog is exposed to, but not bitten by, an animal diagnosed by a veterinarian as rabid, the owner shall observe the dog for a period of one (1) year and report any change in behavior or mannerisms of the dog to the animal control officer and to a veterinarian. 
(e)  If a dog dies during any ten-day confinement period prescribed herein, the owner shall immediately notify the animal control officer and the county health officer. The owner shall make the remains available for rabies examination. The owner shall be responsible for all costs associated with the confinement and/or examination. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99; Ord. No. 99-45, § 1, 12-15-99; Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Sec. 4-68. - Violation; penalties. 
(a)  The following penalties shall apply: 
A person convicted of a violation of this Code or a person who has entered a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere to a violation shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) and shall pay all reasonable court costs. 
(Ord. No. 99-2, § 1, 1-20-99; Ord. No. O2018-013, § 2(Exh. A), 4-4-18) 
Chapter 5 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; refunds of amounts paid for permits issued by any department, § 2-1; planning and zoning board, § 2-136 et seq.; site plan committee, § 2-151 et seq.; right of entry, § 2-171; development services department, § 2-256; code enforcement board, Ch. 6; the bureau of fire prevention shall enforce all laws and ordinances regarding the installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm systems and fire extinguishing equipment and the maintenance and regulation of fire escapes, § 7-42; the bureau of fire prevention or other members of the fire department shall inspect all certain residential structures and business structures, etc., as often as necessary, § 7-47; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; garbage and refuse, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; junked, wrecked, abandoned property, Ch. 11; landscaping, Ch. 12; floodplain management, § 12-541 et seq.; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 13; local improvements and special assessments, Ch. 14; planning and development, Ch. 18; signs and advertising, Ch. 20; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 21; subdivisions, Ch. 22; utilities, Ch. 25; vegetation, Ch. 26; zoning, ch. 27; building department shall maintain elevation records, § 8-22; landscaping plan approval required prior to issuance of building permit, § 12-16; development services department designated to enforce landscaping chapter, § 12-4; inspection required prior to issuance of business tax, § 13-21; building permits and certificates of occupancy; requirements as to subdivision plats, prior to issuance, § 22-16; permits required for removal or destruction of trees, § 26-20.
