Sec. 17-13. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(A)  F.S. Chapter 316. The enforcement of this section may include the enforcement of F.S. § 316.130 (5) as may be amended from time to time. 
(B)  Enforcement procedures. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of any police officer or code inspector of the Town of Davie to enforce the provisions of this chapter; the enforcing officer may require any person seen peddling, or soliciting, in any manner as defined in this chapter to cease such unlawful activity; the police officer or code inspector shall order said violator to a safe location away from or out of roadway traffic whereby the town official and violator may safely engage to enforce the provisions of this chapter; the police officer or code inspector shall request that the violator remove any goods, wares, supplies, inventory, signage, etc., from the prohibited area. 
(2)  As for violations of this town code, a person who violates any part of this chapter may be prosecuted before a county court of competent municipal jurisdiction, where, upon conviction of such violation before the county court judge, s/he shall be subject to the penalties prescribed and adjudged by the county court judge with jurisdiction. Each day of violation of any term or provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct violation. 
(3)  Any person who violates any provision of chapter 17 of the town code may be subject to the code enforcement provisions of chapter 6 of the town code in a prosecution before a town code enforcement special magistrate, and upon a finding of violation, s/he shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 162.09 of that state law and chapter 6 of the town code. 
(Ord. No. 2014-22, § 2, 9-17-14) 
Sec. 17-14. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this chapter or the applicable state law governing such activity, is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-22, § 2, 9-17-14) 
Chapter 18 - COST RECOVERY PROGRAM[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-4, § 4, adopted Feb. 21, 1990, repealed Ch. 18, Planning and Development in its entirety. The users attention is directed to Ch. 12, Land Development Code. Subsequently, Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, adopted Sept. 4, 2002 created a new chapter 18 to read as herein set out. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 18-1. - Title. 
    These regulations shall be known and referred to as the Town of Davie Cost Recovery Program. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02; Ord. No. 2010-12, § 3, 6-16-10) 
Editor's note- Exhibit A is not set out herein but is on file with the Town of Davie. 
Sec. 18-2. - Legislative purpose and intent. 
    The Davie Town Council has hereby determined that the costs related to the review and processing of development applications shall not be subsidized by the general taxpayer and citizenry of the town. Therefore, the town has determined that the most practical and consistently accurate method of defraying the costs of development review and processing functions is through the assessment of fees based upon the actual time expended by town employees and directly associated expenses including but not limited to advertising and legal fees. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Sec. 18-3. - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed herein unless the text indicates otherwise: 
    Alternate cost recovery. A fast track method of cost recovery whereby the applicant of a development application opts to utilize consulting services to review its development application in conjunction with town staff. The town would still recover their costs with town staff serving as project manager and secondary reviewers of the application. 
    Cost recovery account. For accounting purposes an account with the Town of Davie financed by an applicant for the purpose of covering costs incurred during the review and processing of a development application. 
    Cost recovery program. A program established for recovering the full costs of reasonably borne expenses related to the review and processing of development applications such that general revenues are not diverted from general services of a broad nature and thereby utilized to subsidize unfairly and inequitably the resulting development review costs. 
    Direct costs. Those expenses which can be charged directly as a part of the cost of a product or service or a department or operating unit as distinguished from overhead and other indirect costs which must be prorated among several products or services, departments or operative units. 
    Exempted entity. Any individual, partnership, corporation, developer or other association that qualifies for an exemption to the cost recovery program due to its size or other exemption factor. 
    Fringe benefits. Non wage benefits (e.g., paid vacation, life insurance, pensions, etc.) and any other special terms and conditions and privileges of employment which may supplement regular salaries or wages whose cost are borne in whole or part by the town. 
    Major review phases. Individual phases within the town's development review processes including application submission, development review committee (DRC/review, planning & zoning board/site plan committee review, and town council review and approval. In the case of the site plans, a major review phase includes final staff review and approval. 
    Professional service charges. Charges resulting from the use of consultants performing professional services as an alternative to the other methods constituting the cost recovery program 
    Project account. For accounting purposes a separate and singular applicant account under the general cost recovery account relating to a development application. A project account is the financial account associated with each development application in the cost recovery program. 
    Supplemental services. A deemed necessary service requested by an applicant and/or the town administrator or his/her designee for the proper processing of any development application including but not limited to drafting development agreements; reviewing or drafting deed restrictions, drafting or reviewing of special documents including agreements, deeds, conveyances, security instruments, restrictive covenants or special conditions; the preparation, review and analyses of traffic studies, environmental studies and legal analyses; and any action necessary for completion of the development application. This term shall also include any service provided by other town departments, town administrator or outside consultant in excess of those services normally required to review an application for development permit. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Sec. 18-4. - Methods of cost recovery. 
(a)  Cost recovery efforts will be conducted by the town under the following methods. 
(1)  Primary processing method. This method requires the applicant to pay for all costs incurred by the town as a result of employee time spent processing and review of the application (including fringe benefits) and direct costs and expenses attributed to the project. 
(2)  Fast track processing method. Based upon a fee schedule provided by the town, an applicant selects a professional consultant services firm to perform the review of the applicant's development application. The applicant is responsible for professional service charges at the actual cost for the performance of the professional services plus all costs generated by the town staff as project managers, secondary reviewers and administrative oversight of the development application. 
(3)  Supplemental services method. This cost recovery method is basically implemented as the primary processing method excepting that any type of consultant or legal expertise is utilized to supplement the primary method. All additional professional services are charged to the applicant at the actual cost for the performance of the professional service in concert with the town's fee schedule for such services. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Sec. 18-5. - Exemptions. 
(a)  An entity may elect to take an exemption from the cost recovery program if it meets one or several of the criteria outlined in this section. When taking an exemption, the exempted entity shall be required to pay the review and processing fee set in the town's fee schedule for the application type being processed. 
(b)  An exempted entity may qualify for an exemption to the cost recovery program it is meets one or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  Any development applications related to single family property owners; 
(2)  Applications for site plan modifications that expire after the one-year period; 
(3)  Site plan amendment to an existing development that increase/decrease a building foot print by less than twenty (20) percent; 
(4)  Site plan amendment to an existing development that increases/decrease the impervious area by less than twenty (20) percent; 
(5)  Site plan amendments deemed a non-material modification, consistent with Land Development Code Section 12-374(B); 
(6)  Development proposed by any tax-exempt status non-profit agency; 
(7)  Parcels of land zoned B-1, Neighborhood Business or RO, Residential Office and under one (1) acre in size, shall be deemed a small business entity, and likewise, shall be exempt from cost recovery; except that any application which proposes a rezoning from the B-1 or RO District to a more intensive zoning category shall not be entitled to the exemption as an exempted entity. 
(8)  Replats or plats for parcels of land five (5) acres or under in size, when an existing single family home is located on said parcel. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Sec. 18-6. - Processing and review. 
    The following shall apply to the processing for development applications: 
(1)  Fees. Applicants shall be required to pay initial filing fees as adopted by resolution. If additional fees are necessary, the applicant will be asked to pay such fees on or prior to each major review phase of the town's processing procedures. 
(2)  Refunds. In the event that an application is withdrawn within thirty (30) calendar days after an application submittal, non-expended remaining funds will be refunded. No refund will be allowed after this 30-day period. 
(3)  Pre-application meeting. At the time of the required pre-application meeting, staff and the applicant shall determine which method of cost recovery shall be utilized and any supplemental services required, (through mutual consent) as determined due to the nature of the development application. Any supplemental services required after the time of application submittal shall utilize the town's supplemental services consultants, as available. 
(4)  Determination and timing of scope of work and fees. The town shall provide the applicant with a reasonable estimate of any necessary supplemental services within a 30-day time period after the initial application filing. The foregoing should not preclude the town from requesting any additional supplemental services as may be determined throughout the review process. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02; Ord. No. 2010-12, § 3, 6-16-10) 
Sec. 18-7. - Dispute resolution procedures. 
    If any dispute or difference in interpretation arises relative to the imposition of costs, the necessity for supplemental services, or any other related matter between the town and/or the applicant under this chapter or during processing of an application or related approvals, then a dispute resolution process may be invoked according to the following procedures: 
(1)  Within five (5) working days after a request by the applicant and/or the town, the town administrator shall review the disputed matter and make a recommendation to resolve this matter to the affected parties; 
(2)  Any party may request within five (5) working days after the town administrator's determination that the matter be reviewed by the town council. The approval process shall not exceed forty-five (45) calendar days. 
(3)  Processing fees for appeals to the town administrator shall be paid by the applicant ten (10) percent of the original filing fee, pursuant to the fee schedule). 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Sec. 18-8. - Accounting. 
(a)  The town's finance department shall establish an account to be known as the town's cost recovery account. 
(b)  At the time of development application submittal and provision of the initial deposit, a project account shall be established for the development application in accordance with the town's internal accounting procedures. As indicated in section 18-6(1) of this chapter, additional deposits are required of the applicant at each major review phase, as defined in section 18-3(1), of the application's processing. 
(c)  At the town council major review phase the applicant will be required to pay all additional costs in arrears, prior to the item being scheduled before town council. Any additional costs resulting from town council review shall be paid upon invoice by the town. No building permit shall be issued by the town until all cost obligations are satisfied by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Sec. 18-9. - Monitoring and evaluations. 
    The purpose of this section is to ensure that the cost recovery program is recovering the full costs reasonably borne by the taxpayers of the Town of Davie for development review applications through a systematic process established to provide for quarterly monitoring of the overall cost recovery program; and 
    Through the cost recovery program, applicants will be provided with detailed reports indicating the reviews conducted, the charges accrued and the remaining account balances to ensure predictability and efficiencies within the process. 
(1)  Cost recovery program monitoring. 
a.  On a quarterly basis, the Town of Davie shall conduct a review of the cost recovery program and document the following: 
1.  The direct costs of development review, describing and detailing the total hours spent per project account including but not limited to: town staff utilized, professional services utilized, town attorney time, and any other direct costs associated with an application. 
2.  The administrative costs of development review, describing and detailing the total hours spent per project account including, but not limited to: finance department tracking and processing, administrative review, and dispute resolution, if any. 
3.  The staff time and associated billing rates of development review, describing and detailing the following: hours spent per project account, hours spent on the cost recovery program, and professional services utilized and their associated costs. 
4.  The revenues collected through the cost recovery program, describing and detailing the amounts collected per cost recovery account and the amounts generated on a weekly, monthly, and quarterly basis. 
The monitoring is to ensure that all costs expended by the town are being adequately covered to offset additional reliance on taxpayer's dollars for development review. 
(2)  Program evaluation. A monitoring report, based on the above documentation, shall be used to routinely evaluate the success of the cost recovery program to ensure that the overall hours spent by town staff and professional services is equal to the hourly rate, plus benefits (if any) paid and received by the town and charged for professional services under the supplemental services method. 
(3)  Project account monitoring. Throughout the development review process, periodic monitoring of the project account shall be conducted by the assigned project manager. A written report will be presented to the applicant indicating the staff hours spent on the project, the hourly rates accrued through project review, the remaining balance of account, and the remaining anticipated review. 
(Ord. No. 2002-028, § 1, 9-4-02) 
Secs. 18-10-18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IMPACT FEES FOR POLICE, FIRE, PARKS AND RECREATION, AND GENERAL ADMINISTRATION SERVICES 

Sec. 18-21. - Authorization. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to the general police power, the authority granted to municipal corporations by Florida Constitution and Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 2, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-22. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article is for the purpose of requiring that new development pays for its fair share of public facilities through the imposition of impact fees which will be used to finance, defray or reimburse the town for all or a portion of the costs of public facilities which serve such development. The amount of each impact fee shall be calculated based upon the gross square footage of non-residential development, number of residential dwelling units, or other appropriate methodology which insures that the fee is roughly proportional to the impacts of new development on public facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 3, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-23. - Findings. 
    The town council hereby finds that impact fees collected pursuant to this article shall not be used to cure existing deficiencies in level of service. New residential and non-residential development imposes increased and excessive demands upon town public facilities. Planning, economic and demographic studies project that new development will continue and will place ever-increasing demands on the town to provide public facilities to serve the new development. To the extent that new development places demands upon public facilities, those demands should be satisfied by shifting the responsibility for financing the provision of such public facilities from the public to the development creating the demands. The town council, after careful consideration of the Burton & Associates, Inc. - Impact Fee Study results and the experience of other similarly situated towns and cities, finds that the imposition of impact fees to finance specified public facilities, the demand for which is created by new development, is in the best interests of the general welfare of the town and its residents, is equitable, and does not impose an unfair burden on new development. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 4, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-24. - Applicability. 
    Unless expressly excepted or exempted, this article applies to all impact fees imposed by the town to finance public facilities attributable to new development, including without limitation: 
(1)  Police impact fees; 
(2)  Fire impact fees; 
(3)  Parks and recreation impact fees; and 
(4)  General government impact fees. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 5, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-25. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article do not apply to: 
(1)  Taxes and special assessments; 
(2)  Fees for processing development applications; 
(3)  Fees for enforcement of or inspections pursuant to regulatory ordinances; 
(4)  Fees imposed pursuant to a reimbursement agreement between the town and a property owner for that portion of the cost of a public facility paid for by the property owner which exceeds the need for the public facility attributable to, reasonably related to, and roughly proportional to the development; 
(5)  Fees to mitigate impacts on the environment; or 
(6)  Fees imposed, levied or collected by other governmental agencies including subdivisions of the state and federal government. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 6, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-26. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Capital improvement means land, equipment or facilities required to provide the subject service. Capital improvement also includes design, engineering and inspection, testing, planning, legal land acquisition and all other costs associates with construction of a public facility. 
    Collection means the point at which the impact fee is actually paid over to the town. 
    Commitment means earmarking impact fees to fund or partially fund capital improvements serving new development. 
    Dwelling unit means one (1) or more rooms in a building or a portion of a room, designed, intended to be used, or actually used for occupancy by one (1) family for living and sleeping quarters, and containing one (1) kitchen only, and includes a mobile home, but not hotel or motel units. 
    Impact fee means any monetary exaction imposed by the town as a condition of or in connection with approval of a development project for the purpose of defraying all or some of the cost of or repayment of costs previously expended from other town funds for capital improvements relating to the project. 
    Impose means to determine that a particular development project is subject to the collection of impact fees as a condition of development approval. 
    New development or development project means and includes any project undertaken for the purpose of development, including without limitation a project involving the issuance of a permit for construction, reconstruction, of change of use, but not a project involving the issuance of a permit to remodel, reconstruct or replace an existing structure if the remodeled, reconstructed or new structure is not larger than the existing structure if non-residential and does not contain more dwelling units if residential. 
    Non-residential development project means all development other than residential development projects. 
    Residential development project means any development undertaken to create a new dwelling unit or units. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 27, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-27. - Notice and hearing required for establishing or increasing and impact fee. 
(a)  Prior to establishing or increasing of any impact fee, the town council shall hold a public hearing at which oral and written testimony may be given. 
(b)  Notice of the time and place of the public hearing shall be consistent with similar notice requirements of the town, unless specifically required by state statue or other authority. 
(c)  Council action to establish or increase any impact fee shall be taken by resolution. 
(d)  Any costs incurred by the town in preparing for and conduction the public hearing may be recovered as a part of the impact fees which are the subject of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 8, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-28. - Imposition, calculation and collection of impact fees. 
    Except as provided in this article and any amendment to this article, the town shall impose impact fees as a condition of approval of all new development projects. Impact fees shall be collected at the time, and as a condition of issuance of a building permit. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 9, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-29. - Impact fee accounts. 
(a)  The town shall establish an impact fee account for each type of capital improvement for which an impact fee is imposed, and impact fees collected shall be deposited in each such account according to improvement type and the funds of the account shall not be commingled with other funds of the town. 
(b)  Each impact fee account shall be interest bearing and the interest earned shall become a part of the account. 
(c)  The funds of each account shall be expended for the capital improvements for which impact fees were collected. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 10, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-30. - Use of impact fee proceeds. 
    Impact fee proceeds shall be expended only for the type of capital improvements for which they were imposed, calculated and collected and according to the time limits and procedures established in this article. Impact fee may be used to pay the principal, interest and other costs of bonds, notes and other such obligations issued or undertaken by or on behalf of the town to finance such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 11, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-31. - Protests and appeals. 
(a)  A person may protest or challenge the imposition of a fee imposed pursuant to this article by filing with the town clerk within thirty (30) days imposition of the impact fee(s) a written notice of appeal with a full statement of the grounds, and an appeals fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00), or such amount as may be fixed from time to time by resolution of the town council. The town may continue processing the development application if the notice of appeal is accompanied with a bond or other security in an amount equal to the impact fee. 
(b)  At a regular meeting following the fining of the appeal, the town council shall fix a time and place for hearing of the appeal and the town clerk shall mail notice of hearing to the appellant at the address given in the notice of appeal. The hearing shall be conducted at the time and place stated in the notice and the determination of the council shall be announced at the conclusion of the hearing or at the next regular meeting of the council. The determination of the council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 12, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-32. - Variance and exceptions. 
    Petitions for variances or exceptions to the imposition of impact fees shall be made in accordance with the procedures in section 18-31. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 13, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-33. - Credits. 
(a)  A property owner who dedicates land, equipment or facilities or otherwise contributes funds for capital improvements, as defined in this article, may be eligible for a credit for such contribution against the impact fee otherwise due. 
(b)  The town engineer shall determine 1) whether the contribution meets the capital improvement needs for which the particular impact fee has been imposed; and 2) whether the contribution will substitute for or otherwise reduce the need for capital improvements anticipated to be provided with impact fee funds; and 3) the value of the developer contribution. In no event, however, shall the credit exceed the amount of the otherwise applicable impact fee. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 14, 8-19-09) 
Sec. 18-34. - Conflict. 
    In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this article and the provisions of any other ordinance or resolution establishing or amending impact fees, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, § 15, 8-19-09) 
Chapter 19 - POLICE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Additional court cost for law enforcement education and training. 
(a)  An additional court cost of two dollars ($2.00) shall be assessed against any person convicted of violation of a municipal ordinance of the Town of Davie. 
(b)  The two dollars ($2.00) collected shall be paid into the special fund created for the education and training of police officers and support personnel of the town. 
(c)  No such assessment shall be made against any person convicted for violation of any municipal ordinance related to the parking of vehicles. 
(d)  Where a civil penalty is prescribed without a hearing the two dollars ($2.00) shall be deducted from said civil penalty. 
(Code 1964, § 1-14; Ord. No. 83-7, §§ 1, 2, 3-2-83) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 19-2. - Florida statutes hereby adopted. 
    The Town of Davie does hereby adopt the following Florida statutes as currently found or as may be amended from time to time: 
(1)  F.S. § 790.01 Carrying concealed weapons; 
a.  As provided in F.S. § 790.01(4), a person who carries a concealed weapon or electric weapon or device on or about his or her person commits a misdemeanor of the first degree, punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082 or F.S. § 775.083. 
b.  A person who carries a concealed firearm on or about his or her person commits a felony of the third degree, punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082, F.S. § 775.083, or F.S. § 775.084. 
(2)  F.S. § 790.053 Open carrying of a firearm. 
(3)  F.S. § 790.06(12)(a)(7) Concealed weapon or firearm permit. 
A license to carry a concealed weapon or firearm issued under this Florida statute, and as it may be amended from time to time, does not authorize any person to openly carry a handgun or carry a concealed weapon or firearm into any meeting of the governing body of a municipality, or special district. 
(4)  F.S. § 790.15 Discharging a firearm in public; 
(5)  F.S. § 790.151 Using a firearm while under the influence; and, 
(6)  F.S. § 790.10 Improper exhibition of a firearm. 
(7)  F.S. § 790.25 Lawful ownership, possession, and use of firearms and other weapons. 
The lawful ownership, possession, and use of firearms and other weapons shall include those lawful uses as found in section (3) in this Florida statute, and as it may be amended from time to time, including but not limited to that found in subsection (k) of said statute, a person firing weapons in a safe and secure indoor range for testing and target practice. 
(Ord. No. 2011-34, § V, 10-5-11) 
Secs. 19-3-19-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUXILIARY POLICE 

Sec. 19-16. - Appointment. 
    There is hereby established a voluntary organization to be known as auxiliary police composed of persons appointed by the chief of police, hereinafter called the chief, with the approval of the council, said persons to serve as a unit of the police department of the town to assist regular police officers in law enforcement and the maintenance of peace and order. 
(Code 1964, § 11-11) 
Sec. 19-17. - Training required; rules and regulations. 
(a)  No person shall become a member of the auxiliary police until he has taken training and is able to meet all requirements prescribed by the chief. When so qualified, he shall then be sworn in by the chief. 
(b)  In order to effectuate the purpose of the auxiliary police, the chief may by order, establish reasonable rules and regulations to govern the auxiliary police including the fixing of specific duties of its members and providing for the maintenance of discipline. 
(Code 1964, § 11-12) 
Sec. 19-18. - Workmen's compensation; computing amounts. 
(a)  Each member of the auxiliary police while acting under the direction of the chief during a regularly assigned tour of duty, or when receiving instruction or training as provided in this article, shall, for the purposes of workmen's compensation insurance, be deemed an employee of the city and entitled to receive compensation from the city in accordance with F.S. Chapter 440, the Workmen's Compensation Law of the State of Florida, provided such member sustains illness or injury, not caused by his intoxication or wilful misconduct, and not intentionally self-inflicted, which, with or without negligence, is proximately caused by and arises out of and in the course of his duties while acting under the directions of the chief during such tour of duty or training, subject, however, to the limitations hereinafter contained. 
(b)  For the purpose of determining the amount of any compensation payments to be made under the provisions of the Workmen's Compensation Law, irrespective of his remuneration from other employment, the member's average weekly wage shall be taken as follows: 
In computing weekly wages of the injured employee as a basis on which to compute compensation, his average weekly earnings shall be taken as the minimum salary provided for a police officer as in the current pay scale of the town, now in force or as hereinafter amended. 
(c)  It is hereby determined and declared that the intent of the town council is to secure to all auxiliary police complete coverage under the Workmen's Compensation Law, F.S. Chapter 440, being part of the organic law of the State of Florida. 
(Code 1964, § 11-15) 
Chapter 20 - SPECIAL EVENTS 

Sec. 20-1. - Scope. 
    This chapter is intended by the town council to be the framework with which special events as defined in this chapter and held on public or private property in the town are approved and regulated. It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to hold any special event using public or private property within the limits of the town without complying with the permit requirements and procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Applicant shall mean any person or organization desiring to hold a special event that has filed an application for a special event permit. 
    Application shall mean a written request on forms supplied by the special projects department of the town which set forth the information required by this chapter to be provided to the town. 
    Application fee shall mean the nonrefundable fee paid in connection with an application made pursuant to this chapter as may be determined by the town council. 
    Director shall mean, unless otherwise designated by the town administrator, the director of the special projects department of the town. 
    Extra personnel hours shall mean the total number of all hours worked by all town employees in the particular town departments in connection with the production of the special event in question, to the extent such hours exceed the total number of hours which would have been worked by those same town employees in the same location had the special event not have taken place. 
    Parade shall mean a special event with a coordinated movement, except a coordinated movement directly associated with a practice or rite of a well-recognized bona fide religious sect or organization, of eight (8) or more pedestrians or vehicles upon the streets, within the [town] with an intent of attracting public attention that interferes with or has a tendency to interfere with the normal flow or regulation of traffic upon the street. 
    Political demonstration shall mean a public gathering, procession or parade, the primary purpose of which is the exercise of the rights of assembly and free speech guaranteed by the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. The fact that such event may be advertised as a "festival" does not in and of itself bring such a demonstration within the scope of this chapter. 
    Sleeping dragon shall mean a section of pipe, or container filled with weighted material, handcuffs, chains, carabineers, or other locking devices used to lock a person or persons to another person or persons or other objects. 
    Special event shall mean concerts, festivals, races, walks, parades, triathlons, circuses, carnivals, shows, exhibitions, public amusement events by an organization, and other events, whether operated totally outdoors, on stage, under tents or with the use of temporary buildings or structures, upon any parts or portions of public lands or public roads, or upon private lands in the town when members of the public are invited as participants or spectators and which may include entertainment, dancing, music, dramatic presentations, art exhibitions, or the sale of merchandise, food, or alcoholic beverages, or any combination of the foregoing, and which may require for its successful execution the provision and coordination of municipal services to be determined by the town administrator or his/her designee. The definition of event, used in this chapter, does not include events which are solely political demonstrations, unless such political demonstration is proposed as an integral part of a larger event as defined herein. 
    Town-sponsored event shall mean any special event which is in a major part initiated, financed, executed and serviced by the town and its personnel after the approval of the town council is a town-sponsored event. Examples of town-sponsored events include the annual Orange Blossom Parade and Festival or Fourth of July Celebrations. It is not intended to include events in which the town is merely listed as a co-sponsor if the town does not carry a major share of the burden of initiating, financing, executing and providing service personnel for the event. 
    Weapon shall mean, notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, air rifle, air pistol, paintball gun, paintball rifle, explosive blasting cap(s), knife, hatchet, ax, slingshot, blackjack, metal knuckles, mace, iron buckle, ax handle, chains, crowbar, hammer, shovel, or any club or bludgeon or any other instrumentality used or intended for use as a dangerous weapon to cause harm to a person or any public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-3. - Entitlement to special event permit. 
(a)  The town administrator or his/her designee known hereafter as the director, shall be charged with the responsibility of determining whether or not a particular applicant shall be entitled to a special event permit pursuant to this chapter. In determining whether to grant or deny a particular application, the director shall take into account the effect the proposed special event will have upon the town's resources and the public's health and safety. The director shall take into account the frequency with which such events are held and the convenience of the public in relation thereto. In addition, the director shall not issue any special event permit until the following town departments and divisions have approved the application: town administrator or his/her designee, police department, fire department, public works department and the building division. In addition to the above criteria, in making the decision whether to grant or deny a special event permit, the director shall also take the following matters into consideration: 
(1)  Whether the applicant for a special event permit is capable or incapable of executing planned special event; 
(2)  Whether any inconvenience which may be suffered by the general public is outweighed by the potential benefit to the community as a whole; 
(3)  Whether budgetary considerations at the time of the application create such a heavy burden upon the town's financial resources that it would not be practical to hold the proposed special event at the time requested; 
(4)  Whether the holding of the special event as planned would create an undue burden upon the staffing of the town; 
(5)  Whether the public safety would be comprised substantially; 
(6)  The timing of the proposed special event; 
(7)  Whether the applicant producing the special event is profit-making or for charitable or "non-profit" purposes only; and 
(8)  The historical experience, if any, that the town has had with the special event, its sponsoring agent(s), affiliated person(s) or those associated with the current or any former special event in the town. 
(b)  The director shall not issue a special event permit when the director, the police or fire department officials in good faith believe that based upon the information provided by the applicant, the historical experience with such organization or its personnel, or the professional opinions of the town's reviewing authorities that the proposed special event will endanger the public health, safety, welfare and/or lead to the destruction of public or private property. 
(c)  The director shall revoke, suspend or rescind a special event permit already issued when the director, the police or fire department officials in good faith believe that based upon the information provided by the applicant, the historical experience with such organization or its personnel, or the professional opinions of the town's reviewing authorities that allowing the continuation of the proposed special event will endanger the public health, safety or welfare and/or lead to the destruction of public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-4. - Application review process. 
(a)  No person shall initiate, sponsor, organize, promote, conduct or advertise a special event unless a special event permit has been obtained from the town. Any person or organization desiring to hold a special event (the "applicant") shall make an application for a special event permit no later than sixty (60) days prior to the commencement of such event to the director. Such application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee which shall be established by resolution of the town council. 
(b)  In submitting an application for a special event permit, the applicant does thereby agree to adhere to those restrictions or conditions that shall be identified by the director as part of the review and which shall be incorporated into the permit as the terms and conditions for its issuance. 
(c)  The application shall include the following information though the town may request further relevant and material facts to assist with a permit determination: 
(1)  The name of the special event and its general purpose. 
(2)  The name(s) of all person(s) or organization(s) sponsoring the special event, with their addresses and telephone numbers. 
(3)  The proposed date(s) and time(s) of the special event. 
(4)  The specific location(s) within the town where such special event is being held. At the time of application, applicant shall submit a site plan describing the layout of the special event, including the location of every merchandise and/or game booth, music stage, amusement ride, alcoholic beverage and food service locations, public facilities including but not limited to sanitary facilities, trash receptacles, parking areas, etc. 
(5)  When the proposed special event will be held within or near any residential district, the special event sponsors, operators and participants shall adhere to applicable town codes as may be enforced by the town at any time before or during the special event and/or those restrictions and conditions identified by the director as necessary to mitigate any negative impacts upon residents, including but not limited to specific special event activities and uses, the duration of the special event, the hours of operation, the level of amplified music and/or other potential nuisance conditions that may result from the during the special event. 
(6)  The number of persons estimated to be in attendance at such event or festival. 
(7)  Whether any street closings are requested and, if so, which streets and when. 
(8)  Whether any food, beer, wine or other alcoholic beverages are expected to be present and/or sold for public consumption, together with a detailed proposal for such sale, indicating among other things, who is expected to be the vendor or vendors and whether the vendor(s) presently hold any type of state license for the sale and/or consumption of food and alcoholic beverages and providing a copy of said license. 
(9)  State the exact locations and proposed times for any proposed sales of food or alcoholic beverages. 
(10)  Whether any temporary outdoor structures are proposed to be built, describing them in detail. 
(11)  Whether any signs or banners are proposed to be erected, giving details. 
(12)  For nonprofit organization-sponsored events, a proposed budget for the event or festival prepared by the applicant and information on how and to whom the gross revenues shall be allocated as requested by the town. 
(13)  Whether entertainment will be involved, giving details as to the nature, time and place. 
(14)  Whether the applicant proposes, either in whole or in part to hire off-duty personnel of the police department and fire department, to assist in security, traffic control, fire and life safety and/or other matters, giving specific details. 
(15)  Whether utility services such as electrical power or water will be required, specifying the amount and type. 
(16)  Whether electrical wiring shall be installed, specifying installation details. 
(d)  Application review process. Upon receipt of the completed application from the applicant along with the application fee, the director shall forward the application and its contents to the affected departments of the town for review. The person designated in each department shall review the application, endorse their comments thereon and return the comments to the director within ten (10) days of receipt. All comments so forwarded to the director shall be retained in the file for such application. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-5. - Application approval, denial, and appeal procedures. 
(a)  After reviewing the comments of each affected department, the director shall approve or reject the application for the special event permit. 
(b)  If the application is approved, the director shall through consultation, recommendation of a department head, or upon his/her own determination, apply any reasonably necessary restrictions or conditions in accordance with public safety, environmental and administrative considerations involved with the special event, including any reasonable restrictions upon the movement of the public participants which is deemed necessary for the safe and orderly disposition of the special event. 
(c)  The applicant shall comply with all restrictions and conditions imposed by the director, and shall insure that such restrictions and conditions are executed in a timely manner or suffer revocation of the permit; upon the failure of a special event sponsor or operator to comply with any restrictions and conditions imposed thereon by the town before or during the special event, the director may declare the special event as a public nuisance which shall cause the immediate cancellation of the special event permit to occur and closure of the special event. 
(d)  Upon approval of the special event permit by the director the applicant shall obtain all other state, county or town permits no later than thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled special event; failure to comply with all such permit requirements may be good cause leading to the revocation of a special event permit before or during any special event. 
(e)  If the director approves the issuance of the special event permit, the applicant shall obtain said permit upon signing and agreeing to the terms and conditions contained in the agreement referred to in section 20-12, Rights, duties and financial accountability of applicant, which shall include and bind said applicant for any and all financial accountability, and for compliance with all of the requirements in this chapter within three (3) business days of the permit's approval. 
(f)  Any applicant denied a special event permit to conduct a special event shall be notified in writing no later than forty-five (45) days prior to the proposed date of the special event. The notification shall state the reasons for the denial and the right to appeal to the town council, and shall be sent by certified mail to the applicant. 
(g)  Any aggrieved applicant shall be granted a hearing before the town council at a regularly scheduled town council meeting provided the applicant shall make such request to the director in writing within five (5) days of receipt of notification by certified mail. 
(h)  Appeals from the decision of the director, as to the denial of a special event permit, shall be made to the town council. These appeals shall have priority and shall be heard at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the town council; said appeal shall be heard as a quasi-judicial item with sworn testimony and evidence from the applicant, the director or his/her designee allowed. If an attorney shall be representing the applicant, a motion to appear shall be filed no less than five (5) days before the scheduled town council meeting with the town attorney's office that may represent the town. 
(i)  The hearing on such appeals shall be de novo or as if by original jurisdiction. The town council shall hear evidence as to the manner by which the director evaluated the criteria set out in this chapter. The town council shall sustain or reverse the decision of the director in accordance with the town council's judgment as to whether the application meets the standards set out in this chapter. The town council shall make a final decision in the matter and the director shall give written notices thereof to the applicant by mailing a certified letter within five (5) days containing the town council's decision. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-6. - Other required permits to accompany special event permit. 
(a)  Upon the determination of the director, a special event permit may exempt an applicant from a temporary use permit. Any required permits must be applied for separately in accordance with the laws or ordinances specifically governing those activities prior to the issuance of a special event permit. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as repealing other ordinances requiring separate applications for permits or licenses as may be required for specified portions of the proposed special event, such as building permits, licenses to operate amusement rides, licenses for the sale alcoholic beverages, food items, or similarly regulated items. 
(c)  An applicant shall obtain the applicable building permits including, but not limited to electrical, plumbing, mechanical, and structural permits from the town's building official no less than thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled special event. 
(d)  An applicant may be required to obtain other permits pursuant to state law, town ordinances, the Florida Building Code, NFPA, and other laws in effect in Broward County, Florida, as revised from time to time and the permit shall be obtained no less than thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled special event. 
(e)  The building and/or fire department shall make inspections deemed necessary to insure that all building and/or fire code standards are being followed at the special event. Non-compliance with any building and/or fire code standard at any time before or during the special event may be cause for either denial or revocation of the special event permit, or partial revocation of the special event permit and the prohibition of any specific non-complying feature or aspect of the special event. 
(f)  Any person or organization which receives a special event permit shall comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, building and fire codes for the duration of such special event. The person or organization receiving a special event permit shall be responsible for ensuring that its agents, contractors and subcontractors do obtain all necessary permits and comply with all applicable laws, ordinances and fire and building codes. 
(g)  Streets may be closed in connection with a special event at the discretion of the town administrator or his/her designee having due regard to the public safety and environmental effects of such closing, and provided that all reasonable steps are taken to minimize any known adverse impacts upon the community. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-7. - Exemption from special event permit fees. 
(a)  Any special event for which the town, its agencies or agents, CRA, or any other governmental body is the principal sponsor shall be exempt from the special events application fee; however, any costs assessed for town services above the normal routine costs of town operations for police, fire, public works and all other town personnel and services as identified by the town administrator or his/her designee shall be borne by the governmental agency or its agent. 
(b)  Any political demonstration such as a public gathering, procession or parade, the primary purpose of which is the exercise of the rights of assembly and free speech guaranteed by the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States shall be exempt from a special event permit and its fee, unless such political demonstration is proposed as an integral part of a larger event subject to permitting under this chapter. 
(c)  A neighborhood block party, which may request a street closing through the town administrator or his/her designee, is exempt from a special event permit though the event sponsor/operator shall notify the town thirty (30) days prior to the event's proposed date. 
(d)  Film events are required to obtain a film permit from the Broward County Film Commission or similar agency; the owner, sponsor or operator of such a film company shall be required [to] submit such information, including the county approval, with a film/television permit to the town in advance of the film event; no special event fee shall be due for such film/television permit, however the failure of an owner, operator or sponsor of a film event to comply with the aforementioned conditions shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-8. - Town council meetings and related special events. 
(a)  The town council recognizes that special events related to items scheduled for an appearance upon a town council agenda may arise in a spontaneous manner, however in the interest of preserving the public health, safety and welfare, there are necessary and reasonable restrictions and conditions applicable to such special events. For those special events that coincide with political, employee or community issues that may attract assemblies of people numbering greater than eight (8) persons, the town may impose the following restrictions and conditions: 
(1)  No amplified music or speech shall be permitted during the town council meeting; 
(2)  No alcoholic beverages shall be permitted during the town council meeting on public property; 
(3)  The location of persons who may march, parade, or assemble at or in the vicinity of the town council chambers shall at all times permit the normal and unobstructed passage of persons to and from the town council meeting; 
(4)  The location and use of canopies or tents for headquarters, assembly or distribution of flyers, petitions, food items, etc., shall be restricted to one (1) per each group affiliation and the location(s) of such tents or canopies shall be determined by the town administrator or his/her designee after application proposing such use be provided to the director no less than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the commencement of a town council meeting who shall request assistance of any department head as determined by the town administrator. 
(5)  If any operator or sponsor of the march, parade or assembly shall desire to use a tent or canopy, or open air public food preparation and service dispensing location with charcoal, propane or other bar-b-que cooking accessories, utensils or devices, the fire department shall recommend any applicable and required safety precautions to be taken. It is also recommended by the town that a state health certificate or similarly recognized food service manager certification and license be maintained by the operator, preparer and dispenser of any food items, however in lieu of such a certificate, the operator, preparer and dispenser may sign an indemnification and hold harmless agreement releasing the town from any associated liability for said food operations through the town's risk management department in advance of said food service dispensing activity. 
(6)  At no time shall a special event fee be charged to the operators or sponsors of such town council related special events, nor may the public be charged for any accompanying services including food or other items that may be provided by said operators or sponsors. 
(7)  The Davie Town Hall and its lovely grounds are public property and belong to the people of the Town of Davie. The Davie Town Council recognizes this and it is the intent of this chapter that all citizens and employees shall have the unalienable right to assemble, be represented by their collective bargaining agent or union, speak, demonstrate, gather together, rally, celebrate, and or seek redress of grievances. The right to peacefully protest on Davie Town Hall grounds shall remain inviolate and may include the erection of booths or tents and the service of food items in accordance with the standards for safety and sanitation contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-9. - Police services. 
(a)  The chief of police shall determine whether and to what extent additional police protection is reasonably necessary for the special event, parade, or public assembly for traffic control and public safety. The chief of police shall base this decision on the size, location, duration, time and date of the event, the expected sale or service of alcoholic beverages, the number of streets and intersections blocked, and the need to detour or preempt citizen travel and use of the streets and sidewalks. The speech content of the event shall not be a factor in determining the amount of police protection necessary. If possible, without disruption of ordinary police services or compromise of public safety, regularly scheduled on-duty personnel will police the event. If additional police protection is deemed necessary by the chief of police, then the applicant is free to request another time, date and/or location. If the applicant wishes to proceed at the date or time requested and the adequate police services can be provided as an additional expense, then the applicant may request that the permit be issued upon agreement by the applicant to pay the cost of the additional police service. The decision of the police chief shall be final. 
(b)  Non-town sponsored special events will generally be staffed at the existing detail rate in accordance with applicable collective bargaining agreements. If, by virtue of the special risk or high profile nature of the event, the chief of police deems it necessary to involuntarily staff the event with members of the police department, the event may be staffed utilizing overtime. All members working town-sponsored events will be compensated at the overtime rate in accordance with applicable collective bargaining agreements. 
(c)  Persons engaging in special events, parades or public assemblies conducted for the sole purpose of public issue speech protected under the First Amendment are not required to pay for any police protection provided by the town. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-10. - Fire and life safety services. 
(a)  The fire chief or his/her designee shall approve or deny all applications for fireworks displays. 
(b)  The fire chief or his/her designee will determine whether and to what extent additional fire and life safety protection is reasonably necessary for the special event, parade, public assembly or fireworks display. 
(c)  The fire chief shall base this decision on the requirements of the applicable Florida Fire Prevention Code, crowd size, location, duration, and/or time and date of the event, the expected sale or service or alcoholic beverages, and the number of streets and intersections blocked. 
(d)  If additional fire and life safety protection services are deemed necessary by the fire chief or his/her designee, the fire chief shall so inform the applicant for the permit. The applicant then shall have the duty to secure the fire protection deemed necessary by the fire chief at the sole expenses of the applicant. The decision of the fire chief shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-11. - Rights, duties, and financial accountability of an applicant. 
(a)  The applicant shall use the public property solely for the purpose of carrying out the special event as approved by the director, or if through the appeal procedure, as approved by the town council. 
(b)  The applicant shall designate one (1) or more authorized representatives who shall act as the responsible party on the municipal property and who shall be available to the director at all times when the special event or festival is in operation. 
(c)  The applicant shall keep and maintain the public property in a neat, clean and sanitary condition on a regular basis during the time the special event is in operation. 
(d)  The applicant shall be financially responsible for any and all violations of disposal procedures established by the town or any other governmental body having jurisdiction over the public property. 
(e)  The applicant shall be financially responsible for any cleaning, replacement and repair of municipal property or its accompanying articles required to be done by the town after completion of the special event. A surety or cash bond for repairs of potential damage or restoration of town property may be required by the town prior to the special event. 
(f)  The applicant shall be financially responsible for extra personnel hours incurred by the town as a result of the use of municipal personnel, including the department of special projects, parks and recreation, fire department, police department, public works department and any other town departments that may be needed to monitor, check, observe, control or otherwise regulate any phase of the special event, including without limitation any pre-event planning, on-site management of the special event and support in any post-event activities. 
(g)  If the special event requires that personnel hours by town personnel must be extended, the town may require that an applicant post a bond for the approved special event, in an amount to be established by resolution of the town council. The bond shall be applied to the cost of extra personnel hours and/or to any damages and necessary repairs of town property so as to return the town property to its original and working condition as existed before the special event. 
(h)  The town shall return to the applicant any unexpended portion of the bond amount no later than sixty (60) days after the completion of the special event. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-12. - Indemnification and insurance requirements. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of the special event permit, the applicant shall be required to execute an indemnification and hold harmless agreement in a form acceptable to the town attorney. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of the special event permit, the applicant shall maintain, at its sole expense, public liability insurance covering the town properties and the resultant uses thereof, naming the town as an additional insured, in amounts established by the town's risk manager. 
(c)  The applicant shall pay the premiums for the public liability insurance prior to the issuance of the special event permit. The applicant shall furnish and deliver to the director a certificate or certificates of insurance, acceptable to the town risk management division, evidencing the existence of public liability insurance. Each certificate shall provide that the town receive not less than thirty (30) days written notice of cancellation, expiration or termination of public liability insurance. In the event that such insurance is cancelled, expired or terminated, the applicant shall be required to obtain insurance immediately and furnish proof to the director. If such insurance is not obtained within twenty-four (24) hours after cancellation or termination, the director shall revoke the special event permit and the special event shall cease. The applicant shall be responsible for submitting all certificates of insurance of its contractors at the time of filing an application for a special event permit. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-13. - Waiver of financial accountability requirements. 
    For non-profit, charitable or civic organizations, the town council may, by resolution, approve a waiver of all or a portion of the application fee or cost for extra personnel hours. The resolution shall contain the specific monetary amount waived by the town council. Such fee waiver shall be requested by the applicant at the time of application for the special event. In considering whether to waive certain fees provided for in this chapter, the applicant, in addition to submitting an executed application to the director, shall submit to the town council for their review a proposed budget for the proposed special event and a detailed explanation identifying how the gross revenues from the special event will be allocated among specified parties. The town reserves the right to request and review the revenues and expenditures of all special events that receive a waiver in whole or in part. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Sec. 20-14. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  The following prohibitions shall apply to all persons participating in any special event: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person participating in any special event, parade or public assembly to carry or possess any weapon when it may be deemed a violation of any Florida statute. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess any sign, poster, plaque or notice unless such sign, poster, plaque or notice is constructed solely of cloth, paper, or cardboard material no greater than one-quarter-inch in thickness. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess any length of lumber, wood or wood lath, unless the lumber, wood or wood lath shall fall within the following exceptions: both ends of the length of lumber, wood or wood lath shall be blunt, not pointed, with a round or flat edge. The only exceptions from this subsection include: 
(i)  Lumber or wood used to support or control puppets, so long as the lumber or wood is not detached from the puppet; and, 
(ii)  Stilts, defined as two (2) poles with footrests off the ground on which someone balances or walks so long as each stilt does not exceed fifteen (15) feet in length and two (2) inches by two (2) inches in width. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess any length of metal, pvc, plastic or other similar hard or stiff material, whether hollow or solid. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess glass bottles, glass jars or glass containers of any kind, unless such glass container is a vial required to hold medication customarily stored in a glass vial. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess balloons filled with any material or substance other than air, oxygen, or helium. Such materials and substances include, but are not limited to, water, paint, or any other liquid, solid or other gas. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess with the intent to unlawfully use, any hard materials or substances or pieces of hard materials or substances such as bricks, stones, rocks or pieces of asphalt or concrete that are capable of being thrown or projected that may cause injury to persons or property; it shall further be unlawful to remove any hard materials that include but are not limited to typical construction materials such as wood, brick, concrete, asphalt or steel from any construction sites on public or private property during any special event. Any offense of this nature may be prosecuted according to the town's ordinances and the criminal laws of the State of Florida. 
(8)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess: 
(i)  Any spray paint cans or other spray cans that contain toxic materials, liquids or gases including but not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, ammonia, acids or other caustic substances. 
(ii)  Any type of bio-hazardous materials or substances or any type of bottle or similar container that contains toxic materials, liquids or gases, including but not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, ammonia, acids or other caustic substances. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess a projectile launcher or other device which is commonly used for the purpose of launching, hurling, spraying, or throwing any object, liquid or material or other substance including but not limited to, water guns and water cannons. Nothing in this subsection is intended to prohibit or restrict those participating in parades or assemblies from possessing sufficient amount of water or other liquids, designed and intended for human consumption during such special events. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, carry, or possess any so called "sleeping dragon" or similar device. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit a disabled or injured person from carrying, possessing or using a wheelchair, cane, walker or similar device necessary for providing mobility so that a person may participate in a parade or public assembly, and so long as such items are not used as weapons. 
(2)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the performance, display or engagement of any military, police, fire or similar governmental or military honor guard from undertaking any performance that may require the use of devices or items regularly prohibited under the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  Illegal possession or use of items otherwise prohibited by law or regulation. 
(1)  Nothing in this section is intended to authorize the possession or use of materials, substances, weapons or devices that are otherwise prohibited by any state or federal ordinance, statute or regulation. 
(2)  The purpose of this section is to prohibit the carrying or possession of items, materials and substances that have the potential to be used as weapons to cause physical or personal damage, and whose possession is otherwise prohibited by state or federal law. 
(d)  Penalty. 
(1)  Any person convicted of violating any prohibition in this section shall, upon conviction, be penalized as provided in section 1-6 of the Town Code, and may further be subject to the laws of the State of Florida and the federal government as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10; Ord. No. 2011-34, §§ 2(A)VI-VIII, 10-5-11) 
Sec. 20-15. - Enforcement; nuisance; penalties; conflict; severability. 
(a)  In the event that an applicant, its agents, contractors or subcontractors fail to comply with all parts of this chapter or any other ordinances, laws or codes, the town may exercise those police powers that may include but not be limited to the issuance of notices to appear in the county court, code enforcement notices of violation and/or citations, fines and fees commensurate with applicable Florida statutes and town codes and regulations. 
(b)  In addition to said notices, the town may declare that said special event is a public nuisance that endangers the public health, safety and welfare and may deny, revoke or rescind any special event permit with cause. In addition to such enforcement action, the town may determine that an emergency action is necessary and upon a written request from the town administrator or his/her designee to the responsible persons or organization, require that said special event cease to operate at a time to be determined by the town or further determine that the special event shall be shut down immediately. 
(c)  Notwithstanding such declaration of an emergency or other similar town action, the responsible persons, applicant, agents, contractors or subcontractors shall remain responsible to the town for any costs beyond those routine municipal costs derived therefrom and nothing shall bar the town from collecting such fees and costs with applicable interest and the additional costs that may be associated with any legal remedy undertaken by the town through its town attorney. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any provision of this Code, no town elected official, agent, employee or board member shall approve, grant or issue any special event permit, to any named violator with (i) unpaid code enforcement penalties; (ii) unpaid administrative cost recovery fees; (iii) unpaid town attorney costs; or (iv) unpaid liens, any or all of which are owed to the Town of Davie pursuant to the provisions of the Town of Davie Code of Ordinances, Broward County, Florida. 
(e)  Where any provision of chapter 20 is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, electrical, plumbing, fire, safety, or health ordinance, or any regulation adopted pursuant thereto, or any other ordinance, code, or regulation of the town, the more stringent standard shall prevail. 
(f)  If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this chapter is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-33, § 2, 11-17-10) 
Chapter 21 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Refunds of amounts paid for permits issued by departments, § 2-1; civil defense division created, § 2-271 et seq.; consumption and possession of alcoholic beverages in public places prohibited, exceptions, § 3-5; animals running at large prohibited, § 4-42; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; permit required to move any building, house or structure into or upon any street or thoroughfare in the town, § 5-116; excavations prohibited, exceptions, § 5-142; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; garbage and refuse, Ch. 9; littering or accumulation of garbage on streets, sidewalks or other public places, prohibited, § 9-2; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; junked, abandoned, wrecked property, Ch. 11; landscaping, Ch. 12; floodplain management, § 12-541 et seq.; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 17; planning and development, Ch. 18; signs and advertising, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 22; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 24; utilities, Ch. 25; vegetation, Ch. 26; zoning, Ch. 27. 
State Law reference- Uniform minimum standards for roads, F.S. § 335.075. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Drainage swales within public right-of-way. 
(a)  The area immediately adjacent to the paved road surface extending to the right-of-way line or to the edge of the sidewalk is primarily intended for the drainage of the paved roadway by percolation of the water through the natural sand soil. This area is not intended for parking vehicles and overnight parking of commercial vehicles shall be prohibited. It may not be paved with any type of impervious paving or any type of lime rock or stabilizing materials, except as follows: 
(1)  Residential Areas: Paved driveways for access to abutting property. In no event shall this access drive or vehicular stopping area exceed twenty (20) percent of the frontage of the abutting lot. 
(2)  Commercial or Industrial Areas: The above standards for residential areas also apply to commercial or industrial frontage. In the event a larger paved area is desired for parking or access, the owner of the abutting property must provide for subsurface drainage areas or other facilities which will be equal to the additional area which is proposed to be paved. A permit from the public works department must be obtained for this construction. Maintenance of such subsurface drains must be performed by the owner of the abutting property. Prior to application of permit, the owner or owners of the abutting properties shall submit a proposed plan or sketch, including details of construction, to the public works department. 
(b)  Drainage of paved areas on private property shall not drain into the public right-of-way. 
(c)  Sodding of the swale area and right-of-way is encouraged and permitted up to the edge of the paved roadways. 
(d)  Swale areas shall be constructed to conform with the sketch which is on file in the town clerk's office. 
(e)  Appendix "A" made a part hereof by reference and on file in the clerk's office is a diagram illustrating methods, requirements and dimensions for drainage swales for residential and commercial frontage. 
(Code 1964, § 15-15) 
Cross reference- Floodplain management, § 12-541 et seq.; site plan requirements and procedures, § 18-256 et seq. 
Sec. 21-2. - Drainage. 
(a)  All lands, lots and other premises within the town shall be kept properly drained by the owners or occupants thereof, and, in the event the owners or occupants thereof fail or refuse to do so, the town may take such steps as may be necessary, including construction, to provide for the proper drainage at the expense of the owners or occupants thereof, and assess the costs against the owners or occupants, which assessment shall constitute a lien against the property, in the manner and using the same procedures provided for local improvements. 
(b)  The term properly drained as used in this section shall be defined as confining all building and parking area drainage to the property whereon the drainage first appears and disposing of the same through facilities located upon the property or by disposing of the drainage waters into approved public drainage facilities. Drainage waters shall include, but not be limited to, rain, water from hoses and water from sprinkler systems. 
(Code 1964, § 15-16) 
Sec. 21-3. - Driveways. 
(a)  Driveways constructed of concrete in the public right-of-way must conform to the following criteria: 
(1)  There shall be an expansion joint at the property line, completely dividing the slab at this point; 
(2)  No concrete placed in the right-of-way shall contain metal reinforcement. Concrete may be scored or thickened in compliance with the South Florida Building Code and the Specifications of the American Concrete Institute. 
(b)  The cost of repair or replacement of such concrete driveways necessitated by the installation of underground utilities shall be borne by the owner of the property. 
(Code 1964, § 15-15) 
Sec. 21-4. - Parades on public rights-of-way. 
(a)  The council shall be the sole authority for the approval of permits to conduct parades on or about the public rights-of-way of the town. 
(b)  Any civic organization wishing to conduct or sponsor a parade on or about the public rights-of-way of the town shall make application to conduct a parade on a form prescribed by the council. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the application the council shall at a regular or special meeting grant or withhold permission to conduct a parade on or about the public rights-of-way of the town. 
(d)  It shall be at the sole discretion of the council to grant or deny the right to conduct a parade on or about the public rights-of-way of the town and the council shall not have the authority to vest this power in any other town official, elected or appointed. 
(e)  The civic organization making application to conduct a parade on or about the public rights-of-way of the town shall, if approval of the parade is granted by the council, have the sole responsibility and prerogative to determine who the participants and/or participating organizations in the parade shall be. 
(Code 1964, § 15-18) 
Secs. 21-5-21-20. - Reserved.

Sec. 21-22. - Obstructing sidewalk prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to obstruct a sidewalk so as to impede pedestrian traffic. The obstruction to include but is not limited to the parking of motorized vehicles on or across a sidewalk. 
Secs. 21-23-21-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREETS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Permit required to move any building, house or structure into or upon any street or thoroughfare in the town, § 5-116; provisions of the landscaping chapter shall apply to new offstreet parking uses or other vehicular uses, § 12-3; regulation of advertising signs in the public right-of-way, § 20-36; dedication of roads right-of-way for platted and unplatted subdivisions and multi-family development projects, § 22-17; prohibited parking in South New River canal area, § 24-13; off-street parking requirements, § 27-726. 

Sec. 21-36. - Broward County Traffic Ways Plan and set-backs adopted.
